stage.stage: The cherry-orchard scene was effectively produced on a small stage by a blue-green back-drop with a single conventionalized cherry-branch painted across it , and two three-leaved screens masking the wings , painted in blue-green with a spray of cherry blossoms .

A corner of the cherry orchard on the country place of the late Mr. Boggley , now on sale and open for inspection to prospective buyers . The cherry orchard , now in full bloom , is a very pleasant place . There is a green-painted rustic bench beside the path . . . .
A young woman , dressed in a light summer frock and carrying a parasol , drifts in from the back . She sees the bench , comes over to it and sits down with an air of petulant weariness .
A handsome young man enters from the right . He stops short in surprise on seeing the charming stranger who lolls upon the bench . He takes off his hat .

sp.speaker: HE
sp.p: Oh , I beg your pardon !

sp.speaker: SHE
sp.p: Oh , you need n't ! I 've no right to be here , either .

sp.speaker: HE
sp.p: coming over to herNow what do you mean by that ?

sp.speaker: SHE
sp.p: I thought perhaps you were playing truant , as I am .

sp.speaker: HE
sp.p: Playing truant ?

sp.speaker: SHE
sp.p: I was looking at the house , you know . And I got tired and ran away .

sp.speaker: HE
sp.p: Well , to tell the truth , so did I . It 's dull work , is n't it ?

sp.speaker: SHE
sp.p: I 've been upstairs and down for two hours . That family portrait gallery finished me . It was so old and gloomy and dead that I felt as if I were dead myself . I just had to do something . I wanted to jab my parasol through the window-pane . I understood just how the suffragettes felt . But I was afraid of shocking the agent . He is such a meek little man , and he seemed to think so well of me . If I had broken the window I would have shattered his ideals of womanhood , too , I 'm afraid . So I just slipped away quietly and came here .

sp.speaker: HE
sp.p: I 've only been there half an hour and we — I 've only been in the basement . That 's why our tours of inspection did n't bring us together sooner . I 've been cross-examining the furnace . Do you understand furnaces ?He sits down beside herI do n't .

sp.speaker: SHE
sp.p: Do you like family portraits ? I hate ‘ em !

sp.speaker: HE
sp.p: What ! Do the family portraits go with the house ?

sp.speaker: SHE
sp.p: No , thank heaven . They 've been bequeathed to some museum , I am told . They 're valuable historically — early colonial governors and all that sort of stuff . But there is some one with me who — who takes a deep interest in such things .

sp.speaker: HE
sp.p: frowning at a sudden memoryHm . Did n't I see you at that real estate office in New York yesterday ?

sp.speaker: SHE
sp.p: Yes . He was with me then .

sp.speaker: HE
sp.p: compassionatelyI — I thought I remembered seeing you with — with him .

sp.speaker: SHE
sp.p: cheerfullyIs n't he just the sort of man who would be interested in family portraits ?

sp.speaker: HE
sp.p: confusedWell — since you ask me —

sp.speaker: SHE
sp.p: Oh , that 's all right . Tubby 's a dear , in spite of his funny old ideas . I like him very much .

sp.speaker: HE
sp.p: gulping the pillYes ....

sp.speaker: SHE
sp.p: He 's so anxious to please me in buying this house . I suppose it 's all right to have a house , but I 'd like to become acquainted with it gradually . I 'd like to feel that there was always some corner left to explore — some mystery saved up for a rainy day . Tubby can n't understand that . He drags me everywhere , explaining how we 'll keep this and change that — dormer windows here and perhaps a new wing there .... I suppose you 've been rebuilding the house , too ?

sp.speaker: HE
sp.p: No . Merely decided to turn that sunny south room into a study . It would make a very pleasant place to work . But if you really want the place , I 'd hate to take it away from you .

sp.speaker: SHE
sp.p: I was just going to say that if you really wanted it , I 'd withdraw . It was Tubby 's idea to buy it , you know — not mine . You do want it , do n't you ?

sp.speaker: HE
sp.p: I can n't say that I do . It 's so infernally big . But Maria thinks I ought to have it .Explanatorily— Maria is —

sp.speaker: SHE
sp.p: gentlyShe 's — the one who is interested in furnaces . I understand . I saw her with you at the real-estate office yesterday . Well — furnaces are necessary , I suppose .There is a pause , which she breaks suddenly .Do you see that bee ?

sp.speaker: HE
sp.p: A bee ? He follows her gaze up to a cluster of blossoms .

sp.speaker: SHE
sp.p: Yes — there !Affectionately— The rascal ! There he goes . Their eyes follow the flight of the bee across the orchard . There is a silence . Alone together beneath the blossoms , a spell seems to have fallen upon them . She tries to think of something to say — and at last succeeds .

sp.speaker: SHE
sp.p: Have you heard the story of the people who used to live here ?

sp.speaker: HE
sp.p: No ; why ?

sp.speaker: SHE
sp.p: The agent was telling us . It 's quite romantic — and rather sad . You see , the man that built this house was in love with a girl . He was building it for her — as a surprise . But he had neglected to mention to her that he was in love with her . And so , in pique , she married another man , though she was really in love with him . The news came just when he had finished the house . He shut it up for a year or two , but eventually married some one else , and they lived I here for ten years — most unhappily . Then they went abroad , and the house was sold . It was bought , curiously enough , by the husband of the girl he had been in love with . They lived here till they died-hating each other to the end , the agent says .

sp.speaker: HE
sp.p: It gives me the shivers . To think of that house , haunted by the memories of wasted love ! Which of us , I wonder , will have to live in it ? I do n't want to .

sp.speaker: SHE
sp.p: prosaicallyOh , do n't take it so seriously as all that . If one can n't live in a house where there 's been an unhappy marriage , why , good heavens , where is one going to live ? Most marriages , I fancy , are unhappy .

sp.speaker: HE
sp.p: A bitter philosophy for one so young and —

sp.speaker: SHE
sp.p: Nonsense ! But listen to the rest of the story . The most interesting part is about this very orchard .

sp.speaker: HE
sp.p: Really !

sp.speaker: SHE
sp.p: Yes . This orchard , it seems , was here before the house was . It was part of an old farm where he and she — the unhappy lovers , you know — stopped one day , while they were out driving , and asked for something to eat . The farmer 's wife was busy , but she gave them each a glass of milk , and told them they could eat all the cherries they wanted . So they picked a hatful of cherries , and ate them , sitting on a bench like this one . And then he fell in love with her . . . .

sp.speaker: HE
sp.p: And . . . did n't tell her so . . . . She glances at him in alarm . His self-possession has vanished . He is pale and frightened , but there is a desperate look in his eyes , as if some unknown power were forcing him to do something very rash . In short , he seems like a young man who has just fallen in love .

sp.speaker: SHE
sp.p: hastilySo you see this orchard is haunted , too !

sp.speaker: HE
sp.p: I feel it . I seem to hear the ghost of that old-time lover whispering to me . . . .

sp.speaker: SHE
sp.p: provocativelyIndeed ! What does he say ?

sp.speaker: HE
sp.p: He says : “ I was a coward ; you must be bold . I was silent ; you must speak out . ”

sp.speaker: SHE
sp.p: mischievouslyThat 's very curious — because that old lover is n't dead at all . He 's a Congressman or Senator or something , the Agent says .

sp.speaker: HE
sp.p: earnestlyIt 's all the same . His youth is dead ; and it is his youth that speaks to me .

sp.speaker: SHE
sp.p: quickly You must n't believe all that ghosts tell you .

sp.speaker: HE
sp.p: Oh , but I must . For they know the folly of silence — the bitterness of cowardice .

sp.speaker: SHE
sp.p: The circumstances were — slightly — different , were n't they ?

sp.speaker: HE
sp.p: stubbornlyI do n't care !

sp.speaker: SHE
sp.p: soberlyYou know perfectly well it 's no use .

sp.speaker: HE
sp.p: I can n't help that !

sp.speaker: SHE
sp.p: Please ! You simply must n't ! It 's disgraceful !

sp.speaker: HE
sp.p: What 's disgraceful ?

sp.speaker: SHE
sp.p: confusedWhat you are going to say .

sp.speaker: HE
sp.p: simplyOnly that I love you . What is there disgraceful about that ? It 's beautiful !

sp.speaker: SHE
sp.p: It 's wrong .

sp.speaker: HE
sp.p: It 's inevitable .

sp.speaker: SHE
sp.p: Why inevitable ? Ca n't you talk with a girl in an orchard for half an hour without falling in love with her ?

sp.speaker: HE
sp.p: Not if the girl is you .

sp.speaker: SHE
sp.p: But why especially me ?

sp.speaker: HE
sp.p: I do n't know . Love — is a mystery . I only know that I was destined to love you .

sp.speaker: SHE
sp.p: How can you be so sure ?

sp.speaker: HE
sp.p: Because you have changed the world for me . It 's as though I had been groping about in the dark , and then — sunrise ! And there 's a queer feeling here .He puts his hand on his heart .To tell the honest truth , there 's a still queerer feeling in the pit of my stomach . It 's a gone feeling , if you must know . And my knees are weak . I know now why men used to fall on their knees when they told a girl they loved her ; it was because they could n't stand up . And there 's a feeling in my feet as though I were walking on air . And —

sp.speaker: SHE
sp.p: faintlyThat 's enough !

sp.speaker: HE
sp.p: And I could die for you and be glad of the chance . It 's perfectly absurd , but it 's absolutely true . I 've never spoken to you before , and heaven knows I may never get a chance to speak to you again , but I 'd never forgive myself if I did n't say this to you now . I love you ! love you ! love you ! Now tell me I 'm a fool . Tell me to go . Anything — I 've said my say . . . . Why do n't you speak ?

sp.speaker: SHE
sp.p: I — I 've nothing to say — except — except that I — well —almost inaudiblyI feel some of those symptoms myself .

sp.speaker: ME
sp.p: triumphantlyYou love me !

sp.speaker: SHE
sp.p: I — do n't know . Yes . Perhaps .

sp.speaker: HE
sp.p: Then kiss me !

sp.speaker: SHE
sp.p: doubtfullyNo . . . .

sp.speaker: HE
sp.p: Kiss me !

sp.speaker: SHE
sp.p: tormentedlyOh , what 's the use ?

sp.speaker: HE
sp.p: I do n't know . I do n't care . I only know that we love each other .

sp.speaker: SHE
sp.p: after a moment 's hesitation , desperatelyI do n't care , either ! I do want to kiss you .

body.stage: She does . . . . He is the first to awake from the ecstasy .

sp.speaker: HE
sp.p: It is wrong —

sp.speaker: SHE
sp.p: absentlyIs it ?

sp.speaker: HE
sp.p: But , oh heaven ! kiss me again !She does .

sp.speaker: SHE
sp.p: Darling !

sp.speaker: HE
sp.p: Do you suppose any one is likely to come this way ?

sp.speaker: SHE
sp.p: No .

sp.speaker: HE
sp.p: speculativelyYour husband is probably still in the portrait gallery ....

sp.speaker: SHE
sp.p: My husband !Drawing awayWhat do you mean ?Thoroughly awake nowYou did n't think —?She jumps up and laughs convulsively .You thought poor old Tubby was my husband ?

sp.speaker: HE
sp.p: staring up at her bewilderedWhy , is n't he your husband ?

sp.speaker: SHE
sp.p: scornfullyNo !! He 's my uncle !

sp.speaker: HE
sp.p: Your unc —

sp.speaker: SHE
sp.p: Yes , of course !IndignantlyDo you suppose I would be married to a man that 's fat and bald and forty years old ?

sp.speaker: HE
sp.p: distressedI — I beg your pardon . I did think so .

sp.speaker: SHE
sp.p: Just because you saw me with him ? How ridiculous !

sp.speaker: HE
sp.p: It was a silly mistake . But — the things you said ! You spoke so — realistically — about marriage .

sp.speaker: SHE
sp.p: It was your marriage I was speaking about .With hasty compunctionOh , I beg your —

sp.speaker: HE
sp.p: My marriage !He rises .Good heavens ! And to whom , pray , did you think I was married ?A light dawningTo Maria ? Why , Maria is my aunt !

sp.speaker: SHE
sp.p: Yes — of course . How stupid of me .

sp.speaker: HE
sp.p: Let 's get this straight . Are you married to anybody ?

sp.speaker: SHE
sp.p: Certainly not . As if I would let myself be made love to , if I were a married woman !

sp.speaker: HE
sp.p: Now do n't put on airs . You did something quite as improper . You made love to a married man .

sp.speaker: SHE
sp.p: I did n't .

sp.speaker: HE
sp.p: It 's the same thing . You thought I was married .

sp.speaker: SHE
sp.p: But you are n't .

sp.speaker: HE
sp.p: No . I 'm not married . And — and — you 're not married .The logic of the situation striking him all of a suddenIn fact —! He pauses , rather alarmed .

sp.speaker: SHE
sp.p: Yes ?

sp.speaker: HE
sp.p: In fact — well — there 's no reason in the world why we should n't make love to each other !

sp.speaker: SHE
sp.p: equally startledWhy — that 's so !

sp.speaker: HE
sp.p: Then — then — shall we ?

sp.speaker: SHE
sp.p: sitting down and looking demurely at her toesOh , not if you do n't want to !

sp.speaker: HE
sp.p: adjusting himself to the situationWell — under the circumstances — I suppose I ought to begin by asking you to marry me . .

sp.speaker: SHE
sp.p: languidly , with a provoking glanceYou do n't seem very anxious to .

sp.speaker: HE
sp.p: feeling at a disadvantageIt is n't that — but — well —

sp.speaker: SHE
sp.p: lightlyWell what ?

sp.speaker: HE
sp.p: Dash it all , I do n't know your name !

sp.speaker: SHE
sp.p: looking at him with mild curiosityThat did n't seem to stop you a while ago ....

sp.speaker: HE
sp.p: doggedlyWell , then — will you marry me ?

sp.speaker: SHE
sp.p: promptlyNo .

sp.speaker: HE
sp.p: surprisedNo ! Why do you say that ?

sp.speaker: SHE
sp.p: coollyWhy should I marry you ? I know nothing about you . I 've known you for less than an hour .

sp.speaker: HE
sp.p: sardonicallyThat fact did n't seem to keep you from kissing me .

sp.speaker: SHE
sp.p: Besides — I do n't like the way you go about it . If you 'd propose the same way you made love to me , maybe I 'd accept you .

sp.speaker: HE
sp.p: All right .Dropping on one knee before herBeloved !An awkward pauseNo , I can n't do it .He gets up and distractedly dusts off his knees with his handkerchief .I 'm very sorry .

sp.speaker: SHE
sp.p: with calm inquiryPerhaps it 's because you do n't love me any more ?

sp.speaker: HE
sp.p: fretfullyOf course I love you !

sp.speaker: SHE
sp.p: coldlyBut you do n't want to marry me .... I see .

sp.speaker: HE
sp.p: Not at all ! I do want to marry you . But —

sp.speaker: SHE
sp.p: Well ?

sp.speaker: HE
sp.p: Marriage is a serious matter . Now do n't take offense ! I only meant that-well —He starts again .We are in love with each other , and that 's the important thing . But , as you said , we do n't know each other . I 've no doubt that when we get acquainted we will like each other better still . But we 've got to get acquainted first .

sp.speaker: SHE
sp.p: risingYou 're just like Tubby buying a house . You want to know all about it . Well ! I warn you that you 'll never know all about me . So you need n't try .

sp.speaker: HE
sp.p: apologeticallyIt was your suggestion .

sp.speaker: SHE
sp.p: impatientlyOh , all right ! Go ahead and cross-examine me if you like . I 'll tell you to begin with that I 'm perfectly healthy , and that there 's no T. B ., insanity , or Socialism in my family . What else do you want to know ?

sp.speaker: HE
sp.p: hesitantlyWhy did you put in Socialism , along with insanity and T. B .?

sp.speaker: SHE
sp.p: Oh , just for fun . You are n't a Socialist , are you ?

sp.speaker: HE
sp.p: Yes .EarnestlyDo you know what Socialism is ?

sp.speaker: SHE
sp.p: innocentlyIt 's the same thing as Anarchy , is n't it ?

sp.speaker: HE
sp.p: gentlyNo . At least not my kind . I believe in municipal ownership of street cars , and all that sort of thing . I 'll give you some books to read .

sp.speaker: SHE
sp.p: Well , I never ride in street cars , so I do n't care whether they 're municipally owned or not . By the way , do you dance ?

sp.speaker: HE
sp.p: No .

sp.speaker: SHE
sp.p: You must learn right away . I can n't bother to teach you myself , but I know where you can get private lessons and become really good in a month . It is stupid not to be able to dance .

sp.speaker: HE
sp.p: as if he had tasted quinineI can see myself doing the tango ! Grr !

sp.speaker: SHE
sp.p: The tango went out long ago , my dear .

sp.speaker: HE
sp.p: with great decisionWell — I wo n't learn to dance . You might as well know that to begin with .

sp.speaker: SHE
sp.p: And I wo n't read your old books on Socialism . You might as well know that to begin with !

lg.l: Come , come ! This will never do . You see , my dear , it 's simply that
I can n't dance , and there 's no use for me to try to learn .

sp.speaker: SHE
sp.p: Anybody can learn . I 've made expert dancers out of the awkwardest men !

sp.speaker: HE
sp.p: But , you see , I 've no inclination toward dancing . It 's out of my world .

sp.speaker: SHE
sp.p: And I 've no inclination toward municipal ownership . It 's out of my world !

sp.speaker: HE
sp.p: It ought not to be out of the world of any intelligent person .

sp.speaker: SHE
sp.p: turning her back on himAll right — if you want to call me stupid !

sp.speaker: HE
sp.p: turning and looking away meditativelyIt appears that we have very few tastes in common .

sp.speaker: SHE
sp.p: tapping her footSo it seems .

sp.speaker: HE
sp.p: If we married we might be happy for a month —

sp.speaker: SHE
sp.p: Perhaps . They remain with their backs to each other .

sp.speaker: HE
sp.p: And then — the old story . Quarrels . . . .

sp.speaker: SHE
sp.p: I never could bear quarrels . . . .

sp.speaker: HE
sp.p: An unhappy marriage . . . .

sp.speaker: SHE
sp.p: realizing itOh !

sp.speaker: HE
sp.p: hopelessly turning toward herI can n't marry you .

sp.speaker: SHE
sp.p: recovering quickly and facing him with a smileNobody asked you , sir !

sp.speaker: HE
sp.p: with a gesture of finalityWell — there seems to be no more to say .

sp.speaker: SHE
sp.p: sweetlyExcept good-bye .

sp.speaker: HE
sp.p: firmlyGood-by , then . He holds out his hand .

sp.speaker: SHE
sp.p: taking itGood-bye !

sp.speaker: HE
sp.p: taking her other hand — after a pause , helplesslyGood-bye !

sp.speaker: SHE
sp.p: drowning in his eyesGood-bye ! They cling to each other , and are presently lost in a passionate embrace . He breaks loose and stamps away , then turns to her .

sp.speaker: HE
sp.p: Damn it all , we do love each other !

sp.speaker: SHE
sp.p: wiping her eyesWhat a pity that is the only taste we have in common !

sp.speaker: HE
sp.p: Do you suppose that is enough ?

sp.speaker: SHE
sp.p: I wish it were !

sp.speaker: HE
sp.p: A month of happiness —

sp.speaker: SHE
sp.p: Yes !

sp.speaker: HE
sp.p: And then — wretchedness ,

sp.speaker: SHE
sp.p: No — never !

sp.speaker: HE
sp.p: We must n't do it .

sp.speaker: SHE
sp.p: I suppose not .

sp.speaker: HE
sp.p: Come , let us control ourselves .

sp.speaker: SHE
sp.p: Yes , let 'sThey take hands again .

sp.speaker: HE
sp.p: with an effortI wish you happiness . I — I 'll go to Europe for a year . Try to forget me .

sp.speaker: SHE
sp.p: I shall be married when you get back — perhaps .

sp.speaker: HE
sp.p: I hope it 's somebody that 's not bald and fat and forty . Otherwise —!

sp.speaker: SHE
sp.p: And you — for goodness sake ! marry a girl that 's very young and very , very pretty . That will help .

sp.speaker: HE
sp.p: We must n't prolong this . If we stay together another minute —

sp.speaker: SHE
sp.p: Then go !

sp.speaker: HE
sp.p: I can n't go !

sp.speaker: SHE
sp.p: You must , darling ! You must !

sp.speaker: HE
sp.p: Oh , if somebody would only come along ! They are leaning toward each other , dizzy upon the brink of another kiss , when somebody does come — a short , mild-looking man in a derby hat . There is an odd gleam in his eyes .

sp.speaker: THE INTRUDER
sp.p: startledExcuse me ! They turn and stare at him , but their hands cling fast to each other .

sp.speaker: SHE
sp.p: faintlyThe Agent !

sp.speaker: THE AGENT
sp.p: in despairing accentsToo late ! Too late !

sp.speaker: THE YOUNG MAN
sp.p: No ! Just in time !

sp.speaker: THE AGENT
sp.p: Too late , I say ! I will go . He turns away .

sp.speaker: THE YOUNG MAN
sp.p: No ! Stay !

sp.speaker: THE AGENT
sp.p: What 's the use ? It has already begun . What good can I do now ?

sp.speaker: THE YOUNG MAN
sp.p: I 'll show you what good you can do now . Come here !The Agent approaches ., Can you unloose my hands from those of this young woman ?

sp.speaker: THE YOUNG WOMAN
sp.p: haughtily , releasing herself and walking awayYou need n't trouble ! I can do it myself .

sp.speaker: THE YOUNG MAN
sp.p: Thank you . It was utterly beyond my power .To the Agent— Will you kindly take hold of me and move me over there ?The Agent propels him away from the girl .Thank you . At this distance I can perhaps say farewell in a seemly and innocuous manner .

sp.speaker: THE AGENT
sp.p: Young man , you will not say farewell to that young lady for ten days-and perhaps never !

sp.speaker: THE YOUNG WOMAN
sp.p: What !

sp.speaker: THE AGENT
sp.p: They have arranged it all .

sp.speaker: THE YOUNG MAN
sp.p: Who have arranged what ?

sp.speaker: THE AGENT
sp.p: Your aunt , Miss Brooke — andto the young womanyour uncle , Mr. Egerton — The young people turn and stare at each other in amazement .

sp.speaker: THE YOUNG MAN
sp.p: Egerton ! Are you Helen Egerton ?

sp.speaker: HELEN
sp.p: And are you George Brooke ?

sp.speaker: THE AGENT
sp.p: Your aunt and uncle have just discovered each other up at the house , and they have arranged for you all to take dinner together tonight , and then go to a ten-day house-party at Mr. Egerton 's place on Long Island .GrimlyThe reason of all this will be plain to you . They want you two to get married .

sp.speaker: GEORGE
sp.p: Then we 're done for ! We 'll have to get married now whether we want to or not !

sp.speaker: HELEN
sp.p: What ! Just to please them ? I sha n't do it !

sp.speaker: GEORGE
sp.p: gloomilyYou do n't know my Aunt Maria .

sp.speaker: HELEN
sp.p: And Tubby will try to bully me , I suppose . But I wo n't do it — no matter what he says !

sp.speaker: THE AGENT
sp.p: Pardon what may seem an impertinence , Miss ; but is it really true that you do n't want to marry this young man ?

sp.speaker: HELEN
sp.p: flamingI suppose because you saw me in his arms —! Oh , I want to , all right , but —

sp.speaker: THE AGENT
sp.p: mildlyThen what seems to be the trouble ?

sp.speaker: HELEN
sp.p: I — oh , you explain to him , George . She goes to the bench and sits down .

sp.speaker: GEORGE
sp.p: Well , it 's this way . As you may have deduced from what you saw , we are madly in love with each other —

sp.speaker: HELEN
sp.p: from the benchBut I 'm not madly in love with municipal ownership . That 's the chief difficulty .

sp.speaker: GEORGE
sp.p: No , the chief difficulty is that I refuse to entertain even a platonic affection for the tango .

sp.speaker: HELEN
sp.p: irritablyI told you the tango had gone out long ago !

sp.speaker: GEORGE
sp.p: Well , then , the maxixe .

sp.speaker: HELEN
sp.p: Stupid !

sp.speaker: GEORGE
sp.p: And there you have it ! No doubt it seems ridiculous to you .

sp.speaker: THE AGENT
sp.p: gravelyNot at all , my boy . I 've known marriage to go to smash on far less than that . When you come to think of it , a taste for dancing and a taste for municipal ownership stand at the two ends of the earth away from each other . They represent two different ways of taking life . And if two people who live in the same house can n't agree on those two things , they 'd disagree on a hundred things that came up every day . And what 's the use for two different kinds of beings to try to live together ? It does n't work , no matter how much , love there is between them .

sp.speaker: GEORGE
sp.p: rushing up to him in surprise and gratification , and shaking his hand warmlyThen you 're on our side ! You 'll help us not to get married !

sp.speaker: THE AGENT
sp.p: Your aunt is very set on it — and your uncle , too , Miss !

sp.speaker: HELEN
sp.p: We must find some way to get out of it , or they 'll have us cooped up together in that house before we know it .Rising and coming over to the AgentCa n't you think up some scheme ?

sp.speaker: THE AGENT
sp.p: Perhaps I can , and perhaps I can n't . I 'm a bachelor myself , Miss , and that means that I 've thought up many a scheme to get out of marriage myself .

sp.speaker: HELEN
sp.p: outragedYou old scoundrel !

sp.speaker: THE AGENT
sp.p: Oh , it 's not so bad as you may think , Miss . I 've always gone through the marriage ceremony to please them . But that 's not what I call marriage .

sp.speaker: GEORGE
sp.p: Then what do you call marriage ?

sp.speaker: HELEN
sp.p: Yes , I 'd like to know !

sp.speaker: THE AGENT
sp.p: Marriage , my young friends , is an iniquitous arrangement devised by the Devil himself for driving all the love out of the hearts of lovers . They start out as much in love with each other as you two are today , and they end by being as sick of the sight of each other as you two will be five years hence if I do n't find a way of saving you alive out of the Devil 's own trap . It 's not lack of love that 's the trouble with marriage — it 's marriage itself . And when I say marriage , I do n't mean promising to love , honour , and obey , for richer , for poorer , in sickness and in health till death do you part — that 's only human nature to wish and to attempt . And it might be done if it were n't for the iniquitous arrangement of marriage .

sp.speaker: GEORGE
sp.p: puzzledBut what is the iniquitous arrangement ?

sp.speaker: THE AGENT
sp.p: Ah , that 's the trouble ! If I tell you , you wo n't believe me . You 'll go ahead and try it out , and find out what all the unhappy ones have found out before you . Listen to me , my children . Did you ever go on a picnic ?He looks from one to the other — they stand astonished and silent .Of course you have . Every one has . There is an instinct in us which makes us go back to the ways of our savage ancestors — to gather about a fire in the forest , to cook meat on a pointed stick , and eat it with our fingers . But how many books would you write , young man , if you had to go back to the campfire every day for your lunch ? And how many new dances would you invent if you lived eternally in the picnic stage of civilization ? No ! the picnic is incompatible with everyday living . As incompatible as marriage .

sp.speaker: GEORGE
sp.p: But —

sp.speaker: HELEN
sp.p: But —

sp.speaker: THE AGENT
sp.p: Marriage is the nest-building instinct , turned by the Devil himself into an institution to hold the human soul in chains . The whole story of marriage is told in the old riddle : “ Why do birds in their nests agree ? Because if they do n't , they 'll fall out . ” That 's it . Marriage is a nest so small that there is no room in it for disagreement . Now it may be all right for birds to agree , but human beings are not built that way . They disagree , and home becomes a little hell . Or else they do agree , at the expense of the soul 's freedom stifled in one or both .

sp.speaker: HELEN
sp.p: Yes , but tell me —

sp.speaker: GEORGE
sp.p: Ssh !

sp.speaker: THE AGENT
sp.p: Yet there is the nest-building instinct . You feel it , both of you . If you do n't now , you will as soon as you are married . If you are fools , you will try to live all your lives in a love-nest ; and you will imprison your souls within it , and the Devil will laugh .

sp.speaker: HELEN
sp.p: to GeorgeI am beginning to be afraid of him .

sp.speaker: GEORGE
sp.p: So am I .

sp.speaker: THE AGENT
sp.p: If you are wise , you will build yourselves a little nest secretly in the woods , away from civilization , and you will run away together to that nest whenever you are in the mood . A nest so small that it will hold only two beings and one thought — the thought of love . And then you will come back refreshed to civilization , where every soul is different from every other soul — you will let each other alone , forget each other , and do your own work in peace . Do you understand ?

sp.speaker: HELEN
sp.p: He means we should occupy separate sides of the house , I think . Or else that we should live apart and only see each other on week-ends . I 'm not sure which .

sp.speaker: THE AGENT
sp.p: passionatelyI mean that you should not stifle love with civilization , nor encumber civilization with love . What have they to do with each other ? You think you want a fellow student of economics . You are wrong . You think you want a dancing partner . You are mistaken . You want a revelation of the glory of the universe .

sp.speaker: HELEN
sp.p: to George , confidentiallyIt 's blithering nonsense , of course . But it was something like that — a while ago .

sp.speaker: GEORGE
sp.p: bewilderedlyYes ; when we knew it was our first kiss and thought it was to be our last .

sp.speaker: THE AGENT
sp.p: fiercelyA kiss is always the first kiss and the last — or it is nothing .

sp.speaker: HELEN
sp.p: conclusivelyHe 's quite mad .

sp.speaker: GEORGE
sp.p: Absolutely .

sp.speaker: THE AGENT
sp.p: Mad ? Of course I am mad . But — He turns suddenly , and subsides as a man in a , guard 's uniform enters .

sp.speaker: THE GUARD
sp.p: Ah , here you are ! Thought you 'd given us the slip , did you ?To the othersEscaped from the Asylum , he did , a week ago , and got a job here . We 've been huntin ’ him high and low . Come along now !

sp.speaker: GEORGE
sp.p: recovering with difficulty the power of speechWhat — what 's the matter with him ?

sp.speaker: THE GUARD
sp.p: Matter with him ? He went crazy , he did , readin ’ the works of Bernard Shaw . And if he was n't in the insane asylum he 'd be in jail . He 's a bigamist , he is . He married fourteen women . But none of ‘ em would go on the witness stand against him . Said he was an ideal husband , they did . Fourteen of ‘ em ! But otherwise he 's perfectly harmless .

sp.speaker: THE AGENT
sp.p: pleasantlyPerfectly harmless ! Yes , perfectly harmless ! He is led out .

sp.speaker: HELEN
sp.p: That explains it all !

sp.speaker: GEORGE
sp.p: Yes — and yet I feel there was something in what he was saying .

sp.speaker: HELEN
sp.p: Well — are we going to get married or not ? We 've got to decide that before we face my uncle and your aunt .

sp.speaker: GEORGE
sp.p: Of course we 'll get married . You have your work and I mine , and —

sp.speaker: HELEN
sp.p: Well , if we do , then you can n't have that sunny south room for a study . I want it for the nursery .

sp.speaker: GEORGE
sp.p: The nursery !

sp.speaker: HELEN
sp.p: Yes ; babies , you know !

sp.speaker: GEORGE
sp.p: Good heavens !

Miriam Kiper The Fool .................... Duncan MacDougal The Queen ................... Ida Rauh The Sailor .................. George Cram Cook The Prince .................. Pendleton King

stage.stage: The courtyard of a palace . On one side , broad steps , and a door , leading to the palace . On the other , steps leading downward . At the back , a rose-arbour , and in front of it a wide seat .
On the steps before the door a fool is sitting , plucking at a musical instrument . On the lower steps stands an old woman , richly dressed .

sp.speaker: THE OLD WOMAN
sp.p: Why do you sit there , fool , and twang at that harp ? There 's no occasion for making music . Nobody has been winning any battles . How long has it been since a great fight was heard of ?

sp.speaker: THE FOOL
sp.p: If there had been a battle , old woman , they would have had to get some one besides myself to celebrate the winning of it . I do not like fighting .

sp.speaker: THE OLD WOMAN
sp.p: What does a scrawny little weakling like you know of fighting , and why should you have an opinion ?

sp.speaker: THE FOOL
sp.p: The days of fighting are over , and a good thing it is , too . Four kingdoms we have about us , that in the bloody old days we would be for ever marching against , and they against us , killing and burning and destroying the crops till a quiet man would be sick to think of it . But that 's all past . Twenty years we have been at peace with them , and that 's ever since the young queen was born , and I hope it may last as long as she lives .

sp.speaker: THE OLD WOMAN
sp.p: There 's no stopping a fool when he starts to talk . But it is right you are that the good old days are gone . Those were the days of great heroes , like the father of her that is now Queen . They were fine men that stood beside him , and one was my own man . I said to him , “ This is the time a brave man is sure to be killed . If you come back to me , I 'll always think you were a coward . ” He died along with a thousand of the best men in the kingdom fighting around the King . That was a great day . Four kingdoms at once we fought , and beat them to their knees . Glad enough they were to make peace with the child of that dead king .

sp.speaker: THE FOOL
sp.p: Spare me , woman . I 've heard that old story often enough . What do you suppose all that fighting was for , if it was n't to put an end to quarrelling for all time ? If the old King was alive now , he 'd sit in his palace and drink his ale and listen to music , and when he saw the young men giving kisses to the young women under the trees he 'd be glad enough . But you still go cawing for blood , like an old crow .

sp.speaker: THE OLD WOMAN
sp.p: I 'll not talk to such a one . You can see with your own eyes that our enemies are strong and prosperous . We let them into the kingdom with their silks and their satins and their jewels to sell . They walk about the city here and laugh to themselves , thinking how they will spoil and destroy everything soon . It may be this year , it may be next year . If the old King were alive , he 'd never have let them get half so strong . He would have kept them in fear of us , and trained up a fine band of heroes , too , making raids on them once in a while . There 's the city that shoves itself right up against our borders — I can see our men coming home from the spoiling of it , all red with spilt wine and blood . . . .

sp.speaker: THE FOOL
sp.p: You 're a disgusting old woman . If I hear any more of that talk , I 'm likely to slap the face of you , even if you are the Queen 's nurse . Go away before you spoil my afternoon .

sp.speaker: THE OLD WOMAN
sp.p: I could speak to the Queen and have you beaten , do you know that ?

sp.speaker: THE FOOL
sp.p: Woman , go away . I do not want to be bothered by the old and the garrulous . I am composing a love-song .

sp.speaker: THE OLD WOMAN
sp.p: Has any one ever loved you , I would like to know ? Now if it were that young prince who is staying with us , he would have some right to make love-songs — if what they say is true , that every woman he meets on his journey falls in love with him . Even our own Queen , I am thinking . But only three days does he stay in any place , and then he is up and gone on his long journey that nobody understands the reason or the end of , from the east to the west . He is too wise to be held by such toys as love .

sp.speaker: THE FOOL
sp.p: Then he is more a fool than I .

sp.speaker: THE OLD WOMAN
sp.p: Who should know about love , if not a man who has been loved by many women and by great queens ? But you , what do you know about it ?

sp.speaker: THE FOOL
sp.p: The trouble with the old is that they forget so many things . I am sorry for you , woman . You think yourself wise , but the fool that sits at the Queen 's doorstep and looks at her as she passes , and she never seeing him at all , is wiser than you .

sp.speaker: THE OLD WOMAN
sp.p: I have wasted enough words with you . I will go away and sit in the sun and think of the days when there were heroes . She goes .

sp.speaker: THE FOOL
sp.p: And I will make a song about love . I will make a song about the love that is too high for pride and too deep for shame . The door has opened , and the young Queen stands looking down at him .

sp.speaker: THE QUEEN
sp.p: What is that , fool ? What are the words you are saying ?

sp.speaker: THE FOOL
sp.p: kneelingI was speaking of a love that is too high for pride and too deep for shame .

sp.speaker: THE QUEEN
sp.p: And whose love is that , fool ?

sp.speaker: THE FOOL
sp.p: It is the love of all who really love , and it is the only love worth making a song about .

sp.speaker: THE QUEEN
sp.p: smilingAnd how do you come to be so wise as to know about such things ?

sp.speaker: THE FOOL
sp.p: I know because I am a fool .

sp.speaker: THE QUEEN
sp.p: I am well answered . And you are not the only fool in the world , I am thinking . But tell me , fool , have you seen any of the Prince 's men here ?

sp.speaker: THE FOOL
sp.p: No , but I have heard that the ship is being got ready for sailing . . . .

sp.speaker: THE QUEEN
sp.p: rebukinglyI did not ask you that .She is about to go , but turns back , and gives him a piece of money .This is for you to buy wine with and get drunken . You are not amusing when you are sober .She starts to go , but turns again .Fool , do you believe in magic ?

sp.speaker: THE FOOL
sp.p: I have heard that the old wizard who lives in a cave down by the shore is able to rouse storms and keep vessels from sailing .....

sp.speaker: THE QUEEN
sp.p: looking at him , for a moment fixedlyI have a great mind to have you poisoned . Here , take this , and remember that I said to be drunken . She gives him another piece of money , and goes off by way of the rose-trellised passage-way . A sailor comes up the steps .

sp.speaker: THE SAILOR
sp.p: Fool , where is the Prince ?

sp.speaker: THE FOOL
sp.p: I do not know , sailor , but I can tell you what I think .

sp.speaker: THE SAILOR
sp.p: What difference does it make what you think ? I have a message to deliver to him .

sp.speaker: THE FOOL
sp.p: I think that the Queen has sung him to sleep , and that he has not yet awakened .

sp.speaker: THE SAILOR
sp.p: It is likely enough . But I have been sent by the captain , and I must see him .

sp.speaker: THE FOOL
sp.p: You look hot .

sp.speaker: THE SAILOR
sp.p: I am so hot and thirsty that I could drink a barrelful of wine . It is well enough for the Prince to lie about and eat and drink and be sung to by pretty women , but we sailors have work to do . This business of staying only three days in each port disgusts me . No sooner do we get ashore than we have to go back on board again . I saw a girl yesterday , a beauty , and not afraid of a man . There must be many like that here , but what good does it do me ? I spent all my money on her , and now I can n't even get a drink . It 's a shame .

sp.speaker: THE FOOL
sp.p: Would you like a drink ?

sp.speaker: THE SAILOR
sp.p: Fool , do n't make a mock of my thirst , or I 'll twist your neck .

sp.speaker: THE FOOL
sp.p: Look at this .Shows him a coin .

sp.speaker: THE SAILOR
sp.p: What a piece of luck ! Is it real money ? Where did you get it ?

sp.speaker: THE FOOL
sp.p: Your prince gave it to me , and said I was to treat any of his sailors that I came across .

sp.speaker: THE SAILOR
sp.p: Then it 's all right . Why did n't you say so before ? Come along . If you were as thirsty as I am —! They go down the steps . The door opens , and the Prince comes out . He looks up and down .

sp.speaker: THE PRINCE
sp.p: And now begins again my long journey from the east to the west . . . . The old woman appears .

sp.speaker: THE OLD WOMAN
sp.p: Well , have you waked at last ?

sp.speaker: THE PRINCE
sp.p: You are a bitter-tongued old woman . But for all that , I think you are my friend . Perhaps the only friend I have here .

sp.speaker: THE OLD WOMAN
sp.p: You are right . For all that you sleep your holiday away , you are a brave man . And I am the only one in this kingdom that thinks well of bravery . The rest want to smother it with kisses .

sp.speaker: THE PRINCE
sp.p: True enough . I feel that already I am becoming soft . Never before have I been unwilling to leave a city —

sp.speaker: THE OLD WOMAN
sp.p: Or a Queen . . . .

sp.speaker: THE PRINCE
sp.p: I must go on board ship . Is it ready , I wonder ? The captain promised to send word to me . . . .

sp.speaker: THE OLD WOMAN
sp.p: Yes , it is time you went , before they have made a lapdog of you .

sp.speaker: THE PRINCE
sp.p: You speak very freely . Are you not afraid of the Queen ?

sp.speaker: THE OLD WOMAN
sp.p: She does not know what she is doing . She has grown up in a base time of peace , and she does not understand that it is not a man 's business to sleep and drink wine and exchange kisses with pretty queens . She would turn you from your purpose —

sp.speaker: THE PRINCE
sp.p: My purpose ? What do you know of my purpose ?

sp.speaker: THE OLD WOMAN
sp.p: I have not guessed your secret . But I know that you are not merely taking a pleasure journey . I have seen heroes , and you have the eyes of one . The end of all this journeying from the east to the west is something great and terrible — and I will not have you turned aside .

sp.speaker: THE PRINCE
sp.p: Something great and terrible .... Yes ....

sp.speaker: THE OLD WOMAN
sp.p: You have the look of one who does not care for rest or peace or the love of a woman for more than a day . But there is a weakness in you , too . If you would go , go quickly .

sp.speaker: THE PRINCE
sp.p: I wonder why the sailor does not come . It looks like a storm . The sky has become ominously dark .

sp.speaker: THE OLD WOMAN
sp.p: Would a storm hold you back ?

sp.speaker: THE PRINCE
sp.p: Is that what you think of me , old woman ?

sp.speaker: THE OLD WOMAN
sp.p: Well , we shall see what stuff you are made of .... She shuffles off . The Queen enters .

sp.speaker: THE QUEEN
sp.p: coming up to him , tenderlyWhen did you wake ?

sp.speaker: THE PRINCE
sp.p: Did you think your voice had enough magic in it to make me sleep till you returned ? We have just time to say farewell .

sp.speaker: THE QUEEN
sp.p: There is a storm coming up . Do you see how black the sky is ?

sp.speaker: THE PRINCE
sp.p: I am not afraid of storms .

sp.speaker: THE QUEEN
sp.p: Of course you are not afraid of storms . Did you think you had to prove your bravery ?

sp.speaker: THE PRINCE
sp.p: The three days are over .

sp.speaker: THE QUEEN
sp.p: And how quickly !

sp.speaker: THE PRINCE
sp.p: I told you I could stay only three days .

sp.speaker: THE QUEEN
sp.p: I thought you were a king , and could do whatever you chose ....

sp.speaker: THE PRINCE
sp.p: I have chosen to stay only three days .

sp.speaker: THE QUEEN
sp.p: In what way have I offended you ?

sp.speaker: THE PRINCE
sp.p: I made my choice long ago , before I knew you .

sp.speaker: THE QUEEN
sp.p: And now you are afraid to change your mind ?

sp.speaker: THE PRINCE
sp.p: Do you think a brave man changes his mind for pleasure 's sake ?

sp.speaker: THE QUEEN
sp.p: Forgive me . If it is your happiness to go on , to what end I do not know , I will let you . I do not wish to make you unhappy . But I would give you something to take with you , one more flower of my garden , an unfading rose that shall be like a bright memory of me in your heart always . Will you take it ? She leads him back into the palace . The sailor enters , supported by the fool .

sp.speaker: THE SAILOR
sp.p: drunkenlyWhere — where is my Prince ? I have a message for him .

sp.speaker: THE FOOL
sp.p: So you said . But you have n't finished telling me about that girl . Her eyes were blue , you said .

sp.speaker: THE SAILOR
sp.p: Blue , yes . If I said blue , then blue it was . Or maybe green , or grey . Maybe I 'm . thinking of the hussy back in the last port we stopped at . It 's all the same . Reminds me of a little song . Shall I sing you a little song ?

sp.speaker: THE FOOL
sp.p: Another song ? Sing away then .

lg.l: First another drink from this flagon . Ah ! Now I 'm ready .
I 've often been complimented on my voice .
We 'll go no more a-roving-
No , that 's not the one . Let me see . Ah , now I 've got it . Listen .
Blue eyes , grey eyes , green-and-gold eyes ,
Eyes that question , doubt , deny ,
Sudden-flashing , cold , hard , bold eyes ,
Here 's your answer : I am I !
Not for you , and not for any ,
Came I into this man 's town —
Barkeep , here 's my golden penny ,
Come who will and drink it down !
I 'm not one to lend and borrow ,
I 'm not one to overstay —
I shall go alone tomorrow
Whistling , as I came today .
Leave my sword alone , you hussy !
There is blood upon the blade —
Dragon-slaying is a messy
Sort of trade . Put back the blade !
Take my knee and — O you darling !
A man forgets how sweet you are !
Snarling dragons — flowing flagons —
Devil take the morning star !

sp.speaker: THE FOOL
sp.p: Bravo !

sp.speaker: THE SAILOR
sp.p: And there you are ! If I do say it myself , I have as good a time as the Prince does . One girl 's as nice as another — and maybe nicer , at that . What 's a Queen ? Can she kiss better than any other girl ? I 've wondered a bit about it . And the conclusion I 've come to is ... the conclusion I 've come to ...

sp.speaker: THE FOOL
sp.p: The conclusion you 've come to is —?

sp.speaker: THE SAILOR
sp.p: Right you are . Give me that flagon . That 's the stuff . What was I saying ? The conclusion I 've come to is that the Prince can n't have any more fun in three days than any other man . Queen or no Queen . Am I right ? Tell me , am I right ?

sp.speaker: THE FOOL
sp.p: I would n't contradict you ....

sp.speaker: THE SAILOR
sp.p: No . Of course you would n't . You 're a good fellow . You 're my friend . Where 's that flagon ? Ah ! And now it 's your turn to sing . Sing that little song you sang a while ago . That was a good one . You sing almost as well as I do .

sp.speaker: THE FOOL
sp.p: chantsIn this harsh world and old Why must we cherish Fires that grow not cold In hearts that perish ? With the strong floods of hate I cleansed my bosom , But springeth soon and late The fiery blossom . What though some lying tale The mind dissembles ? The scarlet lip turns pale , The strong hand trembles ....

sp.speaker: THE SAILOR
sp.p: No , no , not that one ! That one has n't any tune to it , and it is n't about girls . It 's no song at all . I meant the one — you know — about the young widow . How did it go ?He swigs from the flagon .But I must n't forget the Prince . Where 's that Prince ?

lg.l: Oh , yes , the Prince . Of course . We must n't forget the Prince .
Come along with me .
lg.stage: He leads the sailor off through the rose-arbour . The door of the palace opens , disclosing the Prince and the Queen .
lg.l: He clasps her hands and then descends the steps .

sp.speaker: THE QUEEN
sp.p: Wait ! She runs down , and tenderly embraces him .

sp.speaker: THE PRINCE
sp.p: Farewell .

sp.speaker: THE QUEEN
sp.p: Must you go ?

sp.speaker: THE PRINCE
sp.p: I shall remember you always .

sp.speaker: THE QUEEN
sp.p: bitterlyI suppose that is enough . . . . They come down the steps together .

sp.speaker: THE PRINCE
sp.p: What is that you say ?

sp.speaker: THE QUEEN
sp.p: I say that it is enough that you should think of me sometimes on your long journey from the east to the west . To be remembered — that is the portion of women .

sp.speaker: THE PRINCE
sp.p: You knew what manner of man I was , and that I would not be detained . Why , if you must have the taste of kisses on your lips always , did you not turn to some man of your own land , who would not stray from your side ? Why did you give your love to one you had never seen before , and will never see again ? I did not ask that you love me . What you gave , I took .

sp.speaker: THE QUEEN
sp.p: I regret nothing that I have given . But I am sorry for you , because you do not understand .

sp.speaker: THE PRINCE
sp.p: It may be that I do not understand . But I know that I may not stay longer in this place . Would you ask me to do otherwise ?

sp.speaker: THE QUEEN
sp.p: I would not ask you , no . If you understood , I would have no need of asking . If all things in your life have not changed colour and significance — if I have been to you but as a harlot to one of your sailors ,— then leave me .

sp.speaker: THE PRINCE
sp.p: confusedlyIt is not true that nothing has changed . My mind is in a turmoil . I am dizzy , I cannot see . I have almost forgotten why I set my heart on this journey . You have bewitched me , and that is why I fear you . If I stay here with you any longer , I shall forget everything . I must go .

sp.speaker: THE QUEEN
sp.p: her arms about himYou have forgotten the meaning of your journey . You will not go .

sp.speaker: THE PENCE
sp.p: I am going . . . . But he allows himself to be led to the arbour seat .

sp.speaker: THE QUEEN
sp.p: It is too late . You are mine , now , mine for ever . It was for this that you came hither — I am the meaning of your journey . It was ordained that you love me . You must not think of anything else .

sp.speaker: THE PRINCE
sp.p: Why have you done this to me ? Are you a witch ? I am afraid of you ! He rises .

sp.speaker: THE QUEEN
sp.p: I will teach you strange and terrible secrets .

sp.speaker: THE PRINCE
sp.p: I fear you and yet I trust you . What will come of this I do not know . But I care for nothing . Nothing in the world means anything to me now except you . Why is it that I seem to hate you ? He seizes her and holds her fiercely .

sp.speaker: THE QUEEN
sp.p: That is because you love me at last .

sp.speaker: THE PRINCE
sp.p: I could kill you .

sp.speaker: THE QUEEN
sp.p: You seek in vain to escape love . The sailor staggers in , sees the Prince , and stops .

sp.speaker: THE SAILOR
sp.p: I am bidden to tell you —

sp.speaker: THE PRINCE
sp.p: Be off !— What is it you say ? The Queen stands still , with her hands over her face .

sp.speaker: THE SAILOR
sp.p: The ship is ready .

sp.speaker: THE PRINCE
sp.p: Go ! The sailor walks away .

sp.speaker: THE QUEEN
sp.p: looking after himA word , and you have forgotten me already . A moment ago I thought you loved me . Now I am nothing to you .

sp.speaker: THE PRINCE
sp.p: The ship —

sp.speaker: THE QUEEN
sp.p: It is ready to sail . They are waiting for you . Why do you not go ?

sp.speaker: THE PRINCE
sp.p: I am sorry . But it is as you say . The ship is ready to sail . I must go .

sp.speaker: THE QUEEN
sp.p: Go quickly .

sp.speaker: THE PRINCE
sp.p: Farewell , then .

sp.speaker: THE QUEEN
sp.p: No , stay .She throws herself at his feet , and clasps his knees .See , I beg you to stay . I have no shame left . I beg you . Stay even though you despise me . Stay even though you hate me . I do not care . I will be your slave , your bondwoman . I cannot let you go . She puts her head in her hands , and weeps .

sp.speaker: THE PRINCE
sp.p: looking down at herI am sorry .After a pauseFarewell . He touches her lightly on the shoulder , and , looking toward the sea , leaves her . She rises , and watches him with a stony face until he goes . The fool enters .

sp.speaker: THE QUEEN
sp.p: Are you drunken , fool , as I bade you be ?

sp.speaker: THE FOOL
sp.p: I am drunken , yes , but not with wine . I am drunken with bitterness . With the bitterness of love .

sp.speaker: THE QUEEN
sp.p: Of love , fool ?

sp.speaker: THE FOOL
sp.p: With the bitterness of love . It will amuse you , and so I will tell you what I mean . It is you that I love .

sp.speaker: THE QUEEN
sp.p: Life grows almost interesting once more . But are you not afraid that I will have you whipped ?

sp.speaker: THE FOOL
sp.p: You would have had me whipped a week ago if I had told you this . But now you will not . Now you know what it is to love . . . .

sp.speaker: THE QUEEN
sp.p: My secrets are on a fool 's tongue . But what does it matter ? Go on .

sp.speaker: THE FOOL
sp.p: Why did I try to keep the man you love from going away ? In the hope that one day I should see you kissing him in the garden , and thus I would be spared the trouble of killing myself . In a word , I am a fool . But I have tried to help you . Why did you not keep him ?

sp.speaker: THE QUEEN
sp.p: I have been asking that question of my own heart , fool . I would that I had not come to him a virgin and a Queen , but a light woman skilled in all the ways of love . Then perhaps I could have held him . But now he is gone , and the world is black .

sp.speaker: THE FOOL
sp.p: It is not the world , it is your heart that is black . And it is black with hatred . . . .

sp.speaker: THE QUEEN
sp.p: I think you understand , fool . I would set fire to this palace which the King my father built , I would burn it down tonight , save that it would not make light enough to take away the blackness from my heart . The sailor again , staggering .

sp.speaker: THE QUEEN
sp.p: What , has the ship not gone ?

sp.speaker: THE SAILOR
sp.p: Gone , and left me behind . Gone , and left me . . . .

sp.speaker: THE FOOL
sp.p: Here is still wine in the flagon .

sp.speaker: THE SAILOR
sp.p: Good . Good . Give it to me .

sp.speaker: THE QUEEN
sp.p: to the foolFirst bring it to me .She takes off a ring , and dips it in the wine . To the fool— I have spoken lightly of poisoning today . Now I think I will try it . I would like to see a man die . It will ease me a little . Come ! The sailor comes and takes it from her hands , while the fool stares fascinated .

sp.speaker: THE QUEEN
sp.p: How does it taste ?

sp.speaker: THE SAILOR
sp.p: suddenly straightening up , no longer drunkBitter . What was in it ?

sp.speaker: THE QUEEN
sp.p: The bitterness of my heart . It will kill you .

sp.speaker: THE SAILOR
sp.p: I have been poisoned .He puts his hand to his side .I am dying . But first —! He draws a short sword , and runs at her . The fool starts up , but the Queen motions him away , and waits . When the sailor is almost upon her , he stops , throws up his hands , drops his sword , and falls in a heap .

sp.speaker: THE QUEEN
sp.p: after a moment , going up , and touching the body with her footDead . So that is what it is like ?

sp.speaker: THE FOOL
sp.p: tremblingDo you find it so interesting ?

sp.speaker: THE QUEEN
sp.p: No — my heart is already aching with its emptiness again .... What shall I do ?

sp.speaker: THE FOOL
sp.p: You might poison me , too . I think I would die in a more original manner than that silly sailor . Yes , I would seize you in my arms and kiss you before I died .

sp.speaker: THE QUEEN
sp.p: That would be amusing . But it is a pity to waste kisses on a dying man . And besides , you are the only one in my kingdom who understands me . I must have you alive to talk to .

sp.speaker: THE FOOL
sp.p: There are strange stories about the kisses of queens .

sp.speaker: THE QUEEN
sp.p: Tell them to me .

sp.speaker: THE FOOL
sp.p: There is an old saying that three kisses bestowed by a queen upon a fool will make a hero of him .

sp.speaker: THE QUEEN
sp.p: That might be interesting . I think I will try it . Come to me , do not be afraid . This day I have given my kisses to a man who thought no more of them than that dead sailor there of the kisses of a harlot . What , must you kneel ? Well , then , upon your forehead . She kisses him upon the forehead as he kneels . He slowly rises , and as he rises he takes on dignity . His fool 's cap is dropped aside , he picks up the dead sailor 's sword and girds it on him .

sp.speaker: THE QUEEN
sp.p: Ah , it is true . There is magic in it . You are handsome , too . I am not sorry to have kissed you . The old woman comes in .

sp.speaker: THE QUEEN
sp.p: Well , what is the news ? The ship has sailed , has it not ?

sp.speaker: THE OLD WOMAN
sp.p: Straight into the sunset .She sees the dead man , and looks at the Queen and at the fool .Who killed him ?

sp.speaker: THE QUEEN
sp.p: I killed him . He was left behind , and I do not like to have strangers about .

sp.speaker: THE OLD WOMAN
sp.p: It is a good omen . I have not seen a dead man for twenty years , save those that died of sickness and old age . When shall we have the good old times when men killed each other with swords ? I feel that it is coming . When shall we fall upon the four kingdoms , and tear them to pieces ?

sp.speaker: THE QUEEN
sp.p: Ah , that is an idea . That would be something to do .

sp.speaker: THE FOOL
sp.p: Hush your croakings , old woman , and tell us the news that you have come with .

sp.speaker: THE OLD WOMAN
sp.p: How do you know that I come with news ? Where is your cap , fool ?

sp.speaker: THE FOOL
sp.p: Speak , or be gone .

sp.speaker: THE QUEEN
sp.p: Beware of this man , for I have been making a hero out of him .

sp.speaker: THE OLD WOMAN
sp.p: Are you mad ?

sp.speaker: THE QUEEN
sp.p: Yes , I am mad , so beware of me , too , and tell your news ,

sp.speaker: THE OLD WOMAN
sp.p: tamedIt is only that a boat has been seen to put out from the ship , and is coming back to shore .

sp.speaker: THE QUEEN
sp.p: It is doubtless a present for me . The Prince has bethought himself to pay me for my kindness to him . Go , and give orders that any men who are in the boat are to be brought to me , with their hands tied behind them , that I may decide what punishment to inflict upon them . Let it be understood that we do not like strangers in this kingdom .

sp.speaker: THE OLD WOMAN
sp.p: grimlyIt shall be as you say . She goes out .

sp.speaker: THE QUEEN
sp.p: And now I must finish my quaint task . It pleases me to be kissing fools . I think it is becoming a habit of mine . Come to this garden bench , where he and I sat together , and I will kiss you upon the mouth , as I kissed him . Does it hurt you for me to say that ? Good .They sit down .You are the only one in the kingdom who understands me . Lift up your head .She kisses him . He lifts his head proudly , and sits beside her like a king .You are silent . Why do you not say something appropriate ?

sp.speaker: THE FOOL
sp.p: What I have to say will be with my sword , and your enemies will be the ones to hear it .

sp.speaker: THE QUEEN
sp.p: Ah , I forgot , it is a hero I am making out of you , and all a hero can do is fight . That is a stupid thing . I am sorry now that I kissed you .

sp.speaker: THE FOOL
sp.p: You will not be sorry when I have destroyed your enemies .

sp.speaker: THE QUEEN
sp.p: Now you are beginning to talk like my old nurse . It is well enough to fight , but it should be for amusement , and not with such seriousness . I have only succeeded in making you dull . You were better as a fool . The Prince enters , with his hands tied behind him , conducted by some soldiers .

sp.speaker: THE PRINCE
sp.p: IndignantlyWhy am I treated in this fashion ?

sp.speaker: THE QUEEN
sp.p: So it is you ? She looks at him quietly .

sp.speaker: THE PRINCE
sp.p: haughtilyOrder that these bonds be taken from my wrists .

sp.speaker: THE QUEEN
sp.p: We do not like strangers in this country . You were tied by my command , and brought here that I might decide what punishment to mete out to you . Look , this was one of your men .Pointing to the dead bodyCarry it away . The soldiers carry off the body .

sp.speaker: THE PRINCE
sp.p: Are you mad ?

sp.speaker: THE QUEEN
sp.p: So it would seem .To the foolNow cut his bonds .

sp.speaker: THE FOOL
sp.p: He is a brave man , and does not deserve to be treated in this manner .

sp.speaker: THE PRINCE
sp.p: Who are you that you should plead for me ? Have I not seen you with a fool 's cap ?

sp.speaker: THE FOOL
sp.p: And now you see me with a sword . He cuts the Prince 's bonds .

sp.speaker: THE PRINCE
sp.p: Leave us . I wish to speak with the Queen .

sp.speaker: THE QUEEN
sp.p: to the foolNo , stay .To the PrinceIt is not necessary for you to speak . You wish to tell me that the kisses you had from me were so sweet that you would like to buy some more , and are willing to put off your journey for a while .

sp.speaker: THE PRINCE
sp.p: I have given up my journey for ever . I know that the only thing that is real in all the world is love . You are scornful . But I have neither pride nor shame . I kneel at your feet , and beg you to forgive me for my folly . He kneels .

sp.speaker: THE QUEEN
sp.p: It is a pretty speech . But you are too late . I have forgotten you . While they were tying your hands , I was kissing this man upon the mouth .

sp.speaker: THE PRINCE
sp.p: springing upIt is a lie !

sp.speaker: THE FOOL
sp.p: Did you say that the Queen lies ? He draws his sword .

sp.speaker: THE PRINCE
sp.p: I do not fight with fools .To the QueenSend him away , and have him beaten .

sp.speaker: THE QUEEN
sp.p: Are you not willing to fight with him for me ?

sp.speaker: THE PRINCE
sp.p: What do you mean ?

sp.speaker: THE QUEEN
sp.p: I mean that I have a new appetite , the appetite for death . I have held myself too lightly , I have gone too willingly to the arms of a chance lover . Now there must be blood to sweeten the kisses .

sp.speaker: THE PRINCE
sp.p: Do you wish this fellow killed ?

sp.speaker: THE QUEEN
sp.p: Or you . It makes no difference — not the least . What are my kisses , that I should be careful to whom they go ?

sp.speaker: THE PRINCE
sp.p: You speak strangely , and I hardly know you . I have come back as a lover and not as a butcher .

sp.speaker: THE QUEEN
sp.p: My whim has changed — I am in the mood for butchers , now .

sp.speaker: THE PRINCE
sp.p: Say but one word to show that you still love me !

sp.speaker: THE QUEEN
sp.p: I have no word to say .

sp.speaker: THE PRINCE
sp.p: Doubt makes my sword heavy . . . .

sp.speaker: THE FOOL
sp.p: And have you nothing to say to me ?

sp.speaker: THE QUEEN
sp.p: You remind me . Come . I must finish what I have begun . She kisses him on the mouth — the third kiss .

sp.speaker: THE PRINCE
sp.p: covering his eyesIt is I that am mad .

sp.speaker: THE FOOL
sp.p: Come , if you are not afraid . They go out , the Prince giving one long look at the Queen , whose face remains hard . It has become a dark twilight .

sp.speaker: THE QUEEN
sp.p: They told me that love was like this — but I laughed , and did not believe . The old woman comes in .

sp.speaker: THE QUEEN
sp.p: I have sent him out to die .

sp.speaker: THE OLD WOMAN
sp.p: The fool ?

sp.speaker: THE QUEEN
sp.p: No , no , no , my lover , my beloved . I tortured him and denied him , and sent him out to die .

sp.speaker: THE OLD WOMAN
sp.p: It is well enough . Death is among us again , and the old times have come back . There are sounds of fighting , and the women wait in silence . Then the sounds cease , and slowly the soldiers bear in a dead body , which they lay on the steps . They affix torches to either side of the palace door , and go out .

sp.speaker: THE FOOL
sp.p: going up to the Queen , and holding out his sword to her , hilt-foremostI have done your bidding , and slain a brave man . Bid some one take this sword and slay me .

sp.speaker: THE OLD WOMAN
sp.p: What a faint heart you are ! The fool 's cap is on you still . Put back your sword in your scabbard . You will make a soldier yet .

sp.speaker: THE QUEEN
sp.p: You are a brave man . Put back your sword in your scabbard , and may it destroy all my enemies from this day forth .

sp.speaker: THE FOOL
sp.p: What shall I do ?

sp.speaker: THE QUEEN
sp.p: I have created you , and now I must give you work to do . You can only fight . Very well , then . Take my soldiers , and lead them to the kingdom that thrusts its chief city against our kingdom 's walls . There should be good fighting , and much spoil . When the soldiers have glutted themselves with wine and women , let the city be set on fire . I shall look every night for a light in the sky , and when it comes I shall know it is my bonfire . Perhaps it will light up my heart for a moment . When that is finished , I shall find you other bloody work . Go .

sp.speaker: THE FOOL
sp.p: I understand . You shall have your bonfire . Come , old woman , I want some of your advice .

sp.speaker: THE OLD WOMAN
sp.p: The good old days have come back . Ah , the smell of blood ! They go out . The queen looks over at the dead man lying on the steps between the torches , and gradually her face softens . She goes over slowly , and kneels by his side , gazing on him . She kisses his mouth , and then rises , goes slowly to the arbour , and sits down . She looks away , and her face becomes hard again . A sound of trumpets and shouting , the menacing prelude of war , is heard outside .

stage.head: ENIGMA
A DOMESTIC CONVERSATION
stage.stage: “ Enigma ” was first presented at the Liberal Club , New York City , in 1915 .
A man and woman are sitting at a table , talking in bitter tones .

sp.speaker: SHE
sp.p: So that is what you think .

sp.speaker: HE
sp.p: Yes . For us to live together any longer would be an obscene joke . Let 's end it while we still have some sanity and decency left .

sp.speaker: SHE
sp.p: Is that the best you can do in the way of sanity and decency — to talk like that ?

sp.speaker: HE
sp.p: You 'd like to cover it up with pretty words , would n't you ? Well , we 've had enough of that . I feel as though my face were covered with spider webs . I want to brush them off and get clean again .

sp.speaker: SHE
sp.p: It 's not my fault you 've got weak nerves . Why do n't you try to behave like a gentleman , instead of a hysterical minor poet ?

sp.speaker: HE
sp.p: A gentleman , Helen , would have strangled you years ago . It takes a man with crazy notions of freedom and generosity to be the fool that I 've been .

sp.speaker: SHE
sp.p: I suppose you blame me for your ideas !

sp.speaker: HE
sp.p: I 'm past blaming anybody , even myself . Helen , do n't you realize that this has got to stop ? We are cutting each other to pieces with knives .

sp.speaker: SHE
sp.p: You want me to go . . . .

sp.speaker: HE
sp.p: Or I 'll go — it makes no difference . Only we 've got to separate , definitely and for ever .

sp.speaker: SHE
sp.p: You really think there is no possibility — of our finding some way ?... We might be able — to find some way .

sp.speaker: HE
sp.p: We found some way , Helen — twice before . And this is what it comes to . . . . There are limits to my capacity for self-delusion . This is the end .

sp.speaker: SHE
sp.p: Yes . Only —

sp.speaker: HE
sp.p: Only what ?

sp.speaker: SHE
sp.p: It — it seems . . . such a pity . . . .

sp.speaker: HE
sp.p: Pity ! The pity is this — that we should sit here and haggle about our hatred . That 's all there 's left between us .

sp.speaker: SHE
sp.p: standing upI wo n't haggle , Paul . If you think we should part , we shall this very night . But I do n't want to part this way , Paul . I know I 've hurt you . I want to be forgiven before I go .

sp.speaker: HE
sp.p: standing up to face herCa n't we finish without another sentimental lie ? I 'm in no mood to act out a pretty scene with you .

sp.speaker: SHE
sp.p: That was unjust , Paul . You know I do n't mean that . What I want is to make you understand , so you wo n't hate me .

sp.speaker: HE
sp.p: More explanations . I thought we had both got tired of them . I used to think it possible to heal a wound by words . But we ought to know better . They 're like acid in it .

sp.speaker: SHE
sp.p: Please do n't , Paul — This is the last time we shall ever hurt each other . Wo n't you listen to me ?

sp.speaker: HE
sp.p: Go on . He sits down wearily .

sp.speaker: SHE
sp.p: I know you hate me . You have a right to . Not just because I was faithless — but because I was cruel . I do n't want to excuse myself — but I did n't know what I was doing . I did n't realize I was hurting you .

sp.speaker: HE
sp.p: We 've gone over that a thousand times .

sp.speaker: SHE
sp.p: Yes . I 've said that before . And you 've answered me that that excuse might hold for the first time , but not for the second and the third . You 've convicted me of deliberate cruelty on that . And I 've never had anything to say . I could n't say anything , because the truth was ; too preposterous . It was n't any use telling it before . But now I want you to know the real reason .

sp.speaker: HE
sp.p: A new reason , eh ?

sp.speaker: SHE
sp.p: Something I 've never confessed to you . Yes . It is true that I was cruel to you — deliberately . I did want to hurt you . And do you know why ? I wanted to shatter that Olympian serenity of yours . You were too strong , too self-confident . You had the air of a being that nothing could hurt . You were like a god .

sp.speaker: HE
sp.p: That was a long time ago . Was I ever Olympian ? I had forgotten it . You succeeded very well — you shattered it in me .

sp.speaker: SHE
sp.p: You are still Olympian . And I still hate you for it . I wish I could make you suffer now . But I have lost my power to do that .

sp.speaker: HE
sp.p: Are n't you contented with what you have done ? It seems to me that I have suffered enough recently to satisfy even your ambitions .

sp.speaker: SHE
sp.p: No — or you could n't talk like that . You sit there — making phrases . Oh , I have hurt you a little ; but you will recover . You always recovered quickly . You are not human . If you were human , you would remember that we once were happy , and be a little sorry that all that is over . But you can n't be sorry . You have made up your mind , and can think of nothing but that .

sp.speaker: HE
sp.p: That 's an interesting — and novel — explanation .

sp.speaker: SHE
sp.p: I wonder if I can n't make you understand . Paul — do you remember when we fell in love ?

sp.speaker: HE
sp.p: Something of that sort must have happened to us .

sp.speaker: SHE
sp.p: No — it happened to me . It did n't happen to you . You made up your mind and walked in , with the air of a god on a holiday . It was I who fell — headlong , dizzy , blind . I did n't want to love you . It was a force too strong for me . It swept me into your arms . I prayed against it . I had to give myself to you , even though I knew you hardly cared . I had to — for my heart was no longer in my own breast . It was in your hands , to do what you liked with . You could have thrown it in the dust .

sp.speaker: HE
sp.p: This is all very romantic and exciting , but tell me — did I throw it in the dust ?

sp.speaker: SHE
sp.p: It pleased you not to . You put it in your pocket . But do n't you realize what it is to feel that another person has absolute power over you ? No , for you have never felt that way . You have never been utterly dependent on another person for happiness . I was utterly dependent on you . It humiliated me , angered me . I rebelled against it , but it was no use . You see , my dear , I was in love with you . And you were free , and your heart was your own , and nobody could hurt you .

sp.speaker: HE
sp.p: Very fine — only it was n't true , as you soon found out .

sp.speaker: SHE
sp.p: When I found it out , I could hardly believe it . It was n't possible . Why , you had said a thousand times that you would not be jealous if I were in love with some one else , too . It was you who put the idea in my head . It seemed a part of your super-humanness .

sp.speaker: HE
sp.p: I did talk that way . But I was n't a superman . I was only a damned fool .

sp.speaker: SHE
sp.p: And Paul , when I first realized that it might be hurting you — that you were human after all — I stopped . You know I stopped .

sp.speaker: HE
sp.p: Yes — that time .

sp.speaker: SHE
sp.p: Ca n't you understand ? I stopped because I thought you were a person like myself , suffering like myself . It was n't easy to stop . It tore me to pieces . But I suffered rather than let you suffer . But when I saw you recover your serenity in a day while the love that I had struck down in my heart for your sake cried out in a death agony for months , I felt again that you were superior , inhuman — and I hated you for it .

sp.speaker: HE
sp.p: Did I deceive you so well as that ?

sp.speaker: SHE
sp.p: And when the next time came , I wanted to see if it was real , this godlike serenity of yours . I wanted to tear off the mask . I wanted to see you suffer as I had suffered . And that is why I was cruel to you the second time .

sp.speaker: HE
sp.p: And the third time — what about that ? She bursts into tears , and sinks to the floor , with her head on the chair , sheltered by her arms . Then she looks up .

sp.speaker: SHE
sp.p: Oh , I can n't talk about that — I can n't . It 's too near .

sp.speaker: HE
sp.p: I beg your pardon . I do n't wish to show an unseemly curiosity about your private affairs .

sp.speaker: SHE
sp.p: If you were human , you would know that there is a difference between one 's last love and all that have gone before . I can talk about the others — but this one still hurts .

sp.speaker: HE
sp.p: I see . Should we chance to meet next year , you will tell me about it then . The joys of new love will have healed the pains of the old .

sp.speaker: SHE
sp.p: There will be no more joy or pain of love for me . You do not believe that . But that part of me which loves is dead . Do you think I have come through all this unhurt ? No . I cannot hope any more , I cannot believe . There is nothing left for me . All I have left is regret for the happiness that you and I have spoiled between us . . . . Oh , Paul , why did you ever teach me your Olympian philosophy ? Why did you make me think that we were gods and could do whatever we chose ? If we had realized that we were only weak human beings , we might have saved our happiness !

sp.speaker: HE
sp.p: shakenWe tried to reckon with facts — I cannot blame myself for that . The facts of human nature : people do have love affairs within love affairs . I was not faithful to you . . . .

sp.speaker: SHE
sp.p: rising to her feetBut you had the decency to be dishonest about it . You did not tell me the truth , in spite of all your theories . I might never have found out . You knew better than to shake my belief in our love . But I trusted your philosophy , and flaunted my lovers before you . I never realized —

sp.speaker: HE
sp.p: Be careful , my dear . You are contradicting yourself !

sp.speaker: SHE
sp.p: I know I am . I do n't care . I no longer know what the truth is . I only know that I am filled with remorse for what has happened . Why did it happen ? Why did we let it happen ? Why did n't you stop me ? . . . I want it back !

sp.speaker: HE
sp.p: But , Helen !

sp.speaker: SHE
sp.p: Yes — our old happiness .... Do n't you remember , Paul , how beautiful everything was —?She covers her face with her hands , and then looks up again .Give it back to me , Paul !

sp.speaker: HE
sp.p: torn with conflicting wishesDo you really believe , Helen ...?

sp.speaker: SHE
sp.p: I know we can be happy again . It was all ours , and we must have it once more , just as it was .She holds out her hands .Paul ! Paul !

sp.speaker: HE
sp.p: desperatelyLet me think !

sp.speaker: SHE
sp.p: scornfullyOh , your thinking ! I know ! Think , then — think of all the times I 've been cruel to you . Think of my wantonness — my wickedness — not of my poor , tormented attempts at happiness . My lovers , yes ! Think hard , and save yourself from any more discomfort . . . . But no — you 're in no danger . . . .

sp.speaker: HE
sp.p: What do you mean ?

sp.speaker: SHE
sp.p: laughing hystericallyYou have n't believed what I 've been saying all this while , have you ?

sp.speaker: HE
sp.p: Almost .

sp.speaker: SHE
sp.p: Then do n't . I 've been lying .

sp.speaker: HE
sp.p: Again ?

sp.speaker: SHE
sp.p: Again , yes .

sp.speaker: HE
sp.p: I suspected it .

sp.speaker: SHE
sp.p: mockinglyWise man !

sp.speaker: HE
sp.p: You do n't love me , then ?

sp.speaker: SHE
sp.p: Why should I ? Do you want me to ?

sp.speaker: HE
sp.p: I make no demands upon you . You know that .

sp.speaker: SHE
sp.p: You can get along without me ?

sp.speaker: HE
sp.p: coldlyWhy not ?

sp.speaker: SHE
sp.p: Good . Then I 'll tell you the truth !

sp.speaker: HE
sp.p: That would be interesting !

sp.speaker: SHE
sp.p: I was afraid you did want me ! And — I was sorry for you , Paul — I thought if you did , I would try to make things up to you , by starting over again — if you wanted to .

sp.speaker: HE
sp.p: So that was it . . . .

sp.speaker: SHE
sp.p: Yes , that was it . And so —

sp.speaker: HE
sp.p: harshlyYou need n't say any more . Will you go , or shall I ?

sp.speaker: SHE
sp.p: lightlyI 'm going , Paul . But I think — since we may not meet this time next year — that I 'd better tell you the secret of that third time . When you asked me a while ago , I cried , and said I could n't talk about it . But I can now .

sp.speaker: HE
sp.p: You mean —

sp.speaker: SHE
sp.p: Yes . My last cruelty . I had a special reason for being cruel to you . Sha n't I tell you ?

sp.speaker: HE
sp.p: Just as you please .

sp.speaker: SHE
sp.p: My reason was this : I had learned what it is to love — and I knew that I had never loved you — never . I wanted to hurt you so much that you would leave me . I wanted to hurt you in such a way as to keep you from ever coming near me again . I was afraid that if you did forgive me and take me in your arms , you would feel me shudder , and see the terror and loathing in my eyes . I wanted — for even then I cared for you a little — to spare you that .

sp.speaker: HE
sp.p: speaking with difficultyAre you going ?

sp.speaker: SHE
sp.p: lifting from the table a desk calendar , and tearing a leaf from it , which she holds in front of him . Her voice is tender with an inexplicable regret .Did you notice the date ? It is the eighth of June . Do you remember what day that is ? We used to celebrate it once a year . It is the day —the leaf flutters to the table in front of him— the day of our first kiss . . . . He sits looking at her . For a moment it seems clear to him that they still love each other , and that a single word from him , a mere gesture , the holding out of his arms to her , will reunite them . And then he doubts . . . . She is watching him ; she turns at last toward the door , hesitates , and then walks slowly out . When she has gone he takes up the torn leaf from the calendar , and holds it in his hands , looking at it with the air of a man confronted by an unsolvable enigma .

docTitle.titlePart: IBSEN REVISITED A PIECE OF FOOLISHNESS

titlePage.docImprint: “ Ibsen Revisited ” was first produced at the Liberal Club , in1914, with the following cast :

docTitle.titlePart: The Maid .......... Jo Gotsch The Stranger ...... Floyd Dell

stage.stage: A middle-class interior . The parlour-maid is dusting the furniture .

sp.speaker: THE MAID
sp.p: Oh , how dull it is here ! Nobody to talk to , nobody to flirt with . . . . Flirt ! The men that come to this house do n't even know the meaning of the word . I never worked in such a place . Life is just one long funeral . I wish something would happen .A knock at the door .Ah ! if it were only in the old days , one might hope that that was a reporter . But nothing like that now ! She opens the door . A stranger enters .

sp.speaker: THE STRANGER
sp.p: Is — ah — Miss Gabler in ?

sp.speaker: THE MAID
sp.p: You mean — Mrs. Lovberg ?

sp.speaker: THE STRANGER
sp.p: Yes — but . . . I 'm not mistaken , am I ? Mrs. Lovberg is — or was — Hedda Gabler . Is n't that true ?

sp.speaker: THE MAID
sp.p: Oh , yes , it 's Hedda . But she prefers to be called by her husband 's name . Did you wish to see her ? She is busy just now .

sp.speaker: THE STRANGER
sp.p: Busy ?

sp.speaker: THE MAID
