sp.p: Yes — she is conducting her class in Modern Adolescence .

sp.speaker: THE STRANGER
sp.p: How like Hedda ! Always experimenting with something or other ! What is she teaching them ?

sp.speaker: THE MAID
sp.p: She 's teaching them what she calls “ sex-unconsciousness . ”

sp.speaker: THE STRANGER
sp.p: Dear me ! What is sex-unconsciousness ?

sp.speaker: THE MAID
sp.p: I 'm sure I do n't know , sir .

sp.speaker: THE STRANGER
sp.p: Dear , delightful Hedda ! Ever in pursuit of the new sensation !

sp.speaker: THE MAID
sp.p: You are an old friend of hers , I suppose ?

sp.speaker: THE STRANGER
sp.p: Well , no , not exactly . The fact is —

sp.speaker: THE MAID
sp.p: You 're not a reporter , are you ? Hedda does n't talk to reporters — any more .

sp.speaker: THE STRANGER
sp.p: No . I 'm not a reporter .

sp.speaker: THE MAID
sp.p: What are you , then ?

lg.l: I am the representative of the International Ibsen
Society . You know who Ibsen was , of course ?

sp.speaker: THE MAID
sp.p: Yes — he was that nasty man who wrote plays about everybody 's private affairs .

sp.speaker: THE STRANGER
sp.p: There is that point of view , of course . I 'm sorry to intrude —

sp.speaker: THE MAID
sp.p: I should think you would be ! Now that she and Lovberg are happily married —

sp.speaker: THE STRANGER
sp.p: That 's precisely it . You see , we 've just discovered that instead of committing suicide , as Ibsen made them do in the play , they eloped and were eventually married . You can n't imagine how delighted we all are to discover that Hedda is still alive . As soon as we found that out , I was sent here immediately —

sp.speaker: THE MAID
sp.p: What did you think you would see ?

sp.speaker: THE STRANGER
sp.p: See ? I shall see a woman whose soul burns with an unquenchable flame of divine adventurousness . I shall see the most ardent , impatient , eager , restless , impetuous , and insatiably romantic woman in the world .

sp.speaker: THE MAID
sp.p: pointing to the doorYou mean — her ?

sp.speaker: THE STRANGER
sp.p: Yes — why , there is the very sofa upon which she and Lovberg used to sit , in the old days , discussing his past . There he would sit and tell her of his escapades , his affairs , everything . Tell me , does she insist on Lovberg 's being polygamous , whether he wants to or not ?

sp.speaker: THE MAID
sp.p: Evidently you do n't know the new Hedda . Or the new Lovberg either . The only thing they talk about is what they call “ the monogamist ideal . ”

sp.speaker: THE STRANGER
sp.p: There is some mistake . I will find out when I see her . Surely she is still interested in adventure — the free life — vine - leaves — beauty —! I will remind her of her own past —

sp.speaker: THE MAID
sp.p: No you wo n't . She wo n't let you . She will tell you that too much attention is paid to such foolishness nowadays .

sp.speaker: THE STRANGER
sp.p: She ! who was interested in nothing else ! But then — what is she interested in , now ?

sp.speaker: THE MAID
sp.p: In “ co-operation . ” THE STRANGER , Has she then turned into a mere sociologist ? Oh , you are deceiving me !

sp.speaker: THE MAID
sp.p: If you do n't believe me — I 'll just open the door an inch , and you can hear her talking .

sp.speaker: THE STRANGER
sp.p: Oh , it cannot be true ! The maid quietly opens the door a little way . He listens .

sp.speaker: A VOICE
sp.p: heard through the apertureWe must all learn to function socially . . . . The maid shuts the door again .

sp.speaker: THE MAID
sp.p: Do you believe it now ?

sp.speaker: THE STRANGER
sp.p: sadlyIt is too true !

sp.speaker: THE MAID
sp.p: Did n't I tell you ?

sp.speaker: THE STRANGER
sp.p: So Hedda has become — a reformer !

sp.speaker: THE MAID
sp.p: Yes .

sp.speaker: THE STRANGER
sp.p: And Lovberg — what does he do ?

sp.speaker: THE MAID
sp.p: He is rewriting his book — you know , the one Hedda burned up — for use as a text-book in the public schools . And Hedda is helping him .

sp.speaker: THE STRANGER
sp.p: No more adventure — no more beauty — the flame . . . gone out ! My God ! He staggers toward the wall , where a pistol is hanging , and puts his hand on it .

sp.speaker: THE MAID
sp.p: Look out ! That 's Hedda 's pistol . You never can tell when an old piece of junk like that is loaded .

sp.speaker: THE STRANGER
sp.p: Yes — I know .He takes it down and aims it at his heart .The old Hedda is gone . I cannot bear the new . It would be too —The maid screams— too dull . He fires , and falls .

sp.speaker: THE MAID
sp.p: going over and looking down at himBut — people do n't do such things !

docTitle.titlePart: KING ARTHUR 'S SOCKS A COMEDY To MAX EASTMAN

titlePage.docImprint: “ King Arthur 's Socks ” was first produced by the Provincetown Players ,New YorkCity , in1916, with the following cast : Guenevere Robinson ... Edna James Vivien Smith ......... Jane Burr Mary ................. Augusta Gary Lancelot Jones ....... Max Eastman

stage.stage: The living room of a summer cottage in Camelot , Maine . A pretty woman of between twenty-five and thirty-five is sitting in a big chair in the lamplight darning socks . She is Mrs. Arthur B. Robinson — or , to give her her own name , Guenevere . She is dressed in a light summer frock , and with her feet elevated on a settle there is revealed a glimpse of slender silk-clad ankles . It is a pleasant summer evening , and , one might wonder why so attractive a woman should be sitting at home darning her husband 's socks , there being so many other interesting things to do in this world . The girl standing in the doorway , smiling amusedly , seems to wonder at it too . The girl 's name is Vivien Smith .

sp.speaker: VIVIEN
sp.p: Hello , Gwen !

sp.speaker: GUENEVERE
sp.p: Hello , Vivien ! Come in .

sp.speaker: VIVIEN
sp.p: I 'm just passing by .

sp.speaker: GUENEVERE
sp.p: Come in and console me for a minute or two , anyway . I 'm a widow at present .

sp.speaker: VIVIEN
sp.p: enters and lounges against the mantelpieceArthur gone to New York again ?

sp.speaker: GUENEVERE
sp.p: Yes , for over Sunday . And I 'm lonely .

sp.speaker: VIVIEN
sp.p: You do n't seem to mind . Think of a woman being that happy darning her husband 's socks !

sp.speaker: GUENEVERE
sp.p: Stay here and talk to me — unless you 've something else on . It 's been ages since I 've seen you .

sp.speaker: VIVIEN
sp.p: I 'm afraid I have got something else on , Gwen — I 'll give you one guess .

sp.speaker: GUENEVERE
sp.p: You can n't pretend to be art-ing at this hour of the night .

sp.speaker: VIVIEN
sp.p: I could pretend , but I wo n't . No , Gwen dear , it 's not the pursuit of art , it 's the pursuit of a man .

sp.speaker: GUENEVERE
sp.p: Do n't try to talk like a woman in a Shaw play . I do n't like this rigmarole about “ pursuit . ” Say you 're in love , like a civilized human being . And take a cigarette , and tell me about it .

sp.speaker: VIVIEN
sp.p: lighting a cigaretteI do n't know whether I 'm so civilized , at that . You know me , Gwen . When I paint , do I paint like a lady ?— or like a savage !She does , in fact , appear to be a very headstrong and reckless young woman .

sp.speaker: GUENEVERE
sp.p: mildlyOh , be a savage all you want to , Gwen . But do n't tell me you 're going in for this modern free-love stuff , because I wo n't believe it . You 're not that kind of fool , Vivien .She darns placidly away .

sp.speaker: VIVIEN
sp.p: No , I 'm not . I 'm not a fool at all , Gwen dear . I know exactly what I want — and it does n't include being disowned by my family and having my picture in the morning papers . Free-love ? Not at all . I want to be married .

sp.speaker: GUENEVERE
sp.p: Well , for heaven 's sake , who is it ?

sp.speaker: VIVIEN
sp.p: Is it possible that it 's not being gossiped about ? You really have n't heard ?

sp.speaker: GUENEVERE
sp.p: Not a syllable .

sp.speaker: VIVIEN
sp.p: Then I sha n't tell you .

sp.speaker: GUENEVERE
sp.p: But — why ?

sp.speaker: VIVIEN
sp.p: Because you 'll think I 've a nerve to want him .

sp.speaker: GUENEVERE
sp.p: Nonsense . I do n't know any male person in these parts who is good enough for you , Vivien .

sp.speaker: VIVIEN
sp.p: Thanks , darling . That 's just what I think in my calmer moments . But mostly I 'm so crazy about him that I 'm almost humble . Can you imagine it ?

sp.speaker: GUENEVERE
sp.p: Well , what 's the matter , then ? Does n't he reciprocate ? You do n't look like the victim of a hopeless passion .

sp.speaker: VIVIEN
sp.p: Oh , he 's in love with me all right . But he does n't want to be . He says being in love interferes with his work .

sp.speaker: GUENEVERE
sp.p: What nonsense !

sp.speaker: VIVIEN
sp.p: Oh , I do n't know about that ! I think being in love with me would interfere with a man 's work . I should hope so !

sp.speaker: GUENEVERE
sp.p: primlyI do n't interfere with Arthur 's work .

sp.speaker: VIVIEN
sp.p: Arthur 's a professor of philosophy . Besides , Arthur had written a book and settled down before he fell in love with you . I 'm dealing with a man who has his work still to do . He thinks if he had about three years of peace and quiet and hard work , he 'd put something big across . He put it up to me as a fellow-artist . I know just how he feels . I suppose I am very distracting !

sp.speaker: GUENEVERE
sp.p: Well , why do n't you give him his three years ?

sp.speaker: VIVIEN
sp.p: Gwen ! What do you think I am ? An altruist ? A benefactor of humanity ? Well , I 'm not , I 'm a woman . Three years ? I 've given him three hours , and threatened to marry a man back at home if he does n't make up his mind before then .

sp.speaker: GUENEVERE
sp.p: Heavens , Vivien , you are a savage ! Well , did it work ?

sp.speaker: VIVIEN
sp.p: I do n't know . The three hours are n't up yet . I 'm going around to get my answer now . I must say the prospect is n't encouraging . He started to pack up to go to Boston . He says he wo n't be bullied .

sp.speaker: GUENEVERE
sp.p: But Vivien !

sp.speaker: VIVIEN
sp.p: Oh , do n't condole with me yet , Gwen dear . It 's twelve hours before that morning train , and I 'm not through with him yet .

sp.speaker: GUENEVERE
sp.p: curiouslyWhat are you going to do ?

sp.speaker: VIVIEN
sp.p: Nothing crude , Gwen dear . Oh , there 's lots of things I can do . Cry , for instance . He 's never seen a woman cry . Maybe you think I can n't cry ?

sp.speaker: GUENEVERE
sp.p: It 's hard to imagine you crying .

sp.speaker: VIVIEN
sp.p: I never wanted anything badly enough to cry for it before . But I could cry my heart out for him . I 've absolutely no pride left . Well — I 'm going to have him , that 's all .She throws her cigarette into the grate , and starts to go .

sp.speaker: GUENEVERE
sp.p: And what about his work ? Suppose it 's true —

sp.speaker: VIVIEN
sp.p: Suppose it is . Then his work will have to get along the best way it can .She turns at the door .Do I look like a loser ?— or a winner !

sp.speaker: GUENEVERE
sp.p: I 'll bet on you , Vivien .

sp.speaker: VIVIEN
sp.p: Thanks , darling . And bye-bye .

sp.speaker: GUENEVERE
sp.p: stopping herBut Vivien —! I 've been racking my brain to think who —? Do tell me !

sp.speaker: VIVIEN
sp.p: in the doorway , defiantlyWell , if you must know — it 's Lancelot Jones .

sp.speaker: GUENEVERE
sp.p: springing up , amazed , incredulous and horrifiedOh , no , Vivien ! Not Lancelot !

sp.speaker: VIVIEN
sp.p: Absolutely yes .

sp.speaker: GUENEVERE
sp.p: But — but he 's married already !

sp.speaker: VIVIEN
sp.p: Oh , is that what 's bothering you ?

sp.speaker: GUENEVERE
sp.p: I should rather think it would bother you , Vivien !

sp.speaker: VIVIEN
sp.p: But it so happens that it does n't . I 'm not breaking up a marriage . There is n't any marriage there to break up . I know all about it . Lancelot told me . That marriage was ended long ago . It 's simply that he has never got a divorce .

sp.speaker: GUENEVERE
sp.p: But — but if that 's true , why has n't he got a divorce ?

sp.speaker: VIVIEN
sp.p: On purpose , Gwen — as a protection ! Against love-sick females like me . Against getting married again . I told you he wanted to work .

sp.speaker: GUENEVERE
sp.p: But Vivien ! If he has n't got a divorce —

sp.speaker: VIVIEN
sp.p: He 'll have to get one , that 's all . It wo n't take long . And in the meantime we can be engaged .

sp.speaker: GUENEVERE
sp.p: A funny sort of engagement , Vivien — to a married man !

sp.speaker: VIVIEN
sp.p: I think you 're very unkind , Gwen . It is n't funny at all . It 's a nuisance . We 'll have to wait at least a month ! I think you might sympathize with me . I believe you 're in love with him yourself .

sp.speaker: GUENEVERE
sp.p: coldlyVivien !

sp.speaker: VIVIEN
sp.p: contritelyI 'm sorry . I did n't mean it . But I do think he 's so terribly nice — I do n't see how any woman can help being in love with him . Well — I 'm off to his studio , to learn my fate . Wish me luck , if you can ! She goes .

sp.speaker: GUENEVERE
sp.p: looks after her , then drifts over to the mantel , leans against it staring out into space , and then murmurs— Lancelot ! She goes slowly back to her chair , sits still a moment , and then quietly resumes the darning of socks .

body.stage: Enter , from the side door , Mary , the pretty servant girl , who fusses about at the back of the room .

sp.speaker: GUENEVERE
sp.p: absentlyGoing , Mary ?

sp.speaker: MARY
sp.p: No , ma'am . I do n't feel like going out tonight . Something in her tone makes Guenevere turn .

sp.speaker: GUENEVERE
sp.p: kindlyWhy , Mary , what is the matter ?

sp.speaker: MARY
sp.p: struggling with her sobsI 'm sorry , ma'am , I can n't help it — I was n't going to say anything . But when you spoke to me —

sp.speaker: GUENEVERE
sp.p: quietlyWhat is it , Mary ?

sp.speaker: MARY
sp.p: I 'm a wicked girl .She sobs again .

sp.speaker: GUENEVERE
sp.p: after a moment 's reflection .Yes ? Tell me about it .

sp.speaker: MARY
sp.p: Shall I tell you ?

sp.speaker: GUENEVERE
sp.p: Yes . I think you 'd better tell me .

sp.speaker: MARY
sp.p: I wanted to tell you .She comes to Guenevere , and sinks beside her chair .I wanted to tell you before Mr. Robinson came back . I could n't tell you if he was here .

sp.speaker: GUENEVERE
sp.p: smilingMy husband ? Are you afraid of him , Mary ?

sp.speaker: MARY
sp.p: Yes , ma'am .

sp.speaker: GUENEVERE
sp.p: to herselfPoor Arthur ! He does frighten people . He looks so — just .

sp.speaker: MARY
sp.p: That 's what it is , ma'am . He always makes me think of my father .

sp.speaker: GUENEVERE
sp.p: Is your father a just man , too , Mary ?

sp.speaker: MARY
sp.p: Yes , ma'am . He 's that just I 'd never dare breathe a word to him about what I 've done . He 'd put me out of the house .

sp.speaker: GUENEVERE
sp.p: hesitatingIs it so bad , Mary , what you have done ?

sp.speaker: MARY
sp.p: Yes , ma'am .

sp.speaker: GUENEVERE
sp.p: Do you — do you want to tell me who it is ?

sp.speaker: MARY
sp.p: It 's Mr. Jones , ma'am .

sp.speaker: GUENEVERE
sp.p: reflectivelyJones ?Then , astoundedly— Jones !Incredulously— You do n't mean —!Quietly— Do you mean Mr. Lancelot Jones ?

sp.speaker: MARY
sp.p: Yes , ma'am .

sp.speaker: GUENEVERE
sp.p: This is terrible ! When did it happen ?

sp.speaker: MARY
sp.p: It — it sort of happened last night , ma'am . It was this way —

sp.speaker: GUENEVERE
sp.p: No details , please !

lg.l: No , ma'am . I just wanted to tell you how it was . You see , ma'am ,
I went to his studio —

sp.speaker: GUENEVERE
sp.p: unable to bear itPlease , Mary , please !

sp.speaker: MARY
sp.p: Yes , ma'am .

sp.speaker: GUENEVERE
sp.p: I do n't mean that I blame you . One can n't help — falling in love ....

sp.speaker: MARY
sp.p: No , you just can n't help it , can you ?

sp.speaker: GUENEVERE
sp.p: But Lancelot — Mr. Jones — should have behaved better than that ....

sp.speaker: MARY
sp.p: Should he , ma'am ?

sp.speaker: GUENEVERE
sp.p: He certainly should . I would n't have believed it of him . So that is why — Mary ! Do you know —? But I 'm not sure that I ought to tell you . Still , I do n't see why I should protect him . Do you know that he is going away ?

sp.speaker: MARY
sp.p: No , ma'am . Is he ?

sp.speaker: GUENEVERE
sp.p: Yes . In the mo'rning . You must go to see him tonight . No , you can n't do that .... Oh , this is terrible !

sp.speaker: MARY
sp.p: I 'm glad he 's going away , Mrs. Robinson .

sp.speaker: GUENEVERE
sp.p: Are you ?

sp.speaker: MARY
sp.p: Yes , ma'am .

sp.speaker: GUENEVERE
sp.p: Why ?

sp.speaker: MARY
sp.p: Because I 'd be so ashamed every time I saw him .

sp.speaker: GUENEVERE
sp.p: looking at her with interestReally ? I did n't know people felt that way . Perhaps it 's the right way to feel . But I did n't suppose anybody did . So you want him to go ?

sp.speaker: MARY
sp.p: Yes , ma'am .

sp.speaker: GUENEVERE
sp.p: And you do n't feel you 've any claim on him ?

sp.speaker: MARY
sp.p: No , ma'am . Why should I ?

sp.speaker: GUENEVERE
sp.p: Well ! I really do n't know . But one is supposed to . Mary , you are a modern woman !

sp.speaker: MARY
sp.p: Am I ?

sp.speaker: GUENEVERE
sp.p: One would think , after what happened —

sp.speaker: MARY
sp.p: That 's just it , ma'am . If it had been anything else — But after what happened , I just want never to see him again . You see , ma'am , it was this way —

sp.speaker: GUENEVERE
sp.p: gentlyIs it necessary to tell me that , Mary ? I know what happened .

sp.speaker: MARY
sp.p: But you do n't , ma'am . That 's just it . I 've been trying to tell you what happened , ma'am .

sp.speaker: GUENEVERE
sp.p: Good heavens , was it so horrible ! Well , go on , then .She nerves herself to hear the worst .What did happen ?

sp.speaker: MARY
sp.p: Nothing , ma'am ....

sp.speaker: GUENEVERE
sp.p: Nothing ?

sp.speaker: MARY
sp.p: That 's just it ....

sp.speaker: GUENEVERE
sp.p: But I — I do n't understand .

sp.speaker: MARY
sp.p: You said a while ago , Mrs. Robinson , that you could n't help falling in love . It 's true . I tried every way to stop , but I could n't . So last night I — I went to his studio —

sp.speaker: GUENEVERE
sp.p: Yes ?

sp.speaker: MARY
sp.p: I told you I was a wicked girl , Mrs. Robinson . You know I 've a key to let myself in to clean up for him . So last night I just went in . He — he was asleep —

sp.speaker: GUENEVERE
sp.p: Yes ?

sp.speaker: MARY
sp.p: I — shall I tell you , ma'am ?

sp.speaker: GUENEVERE
sp.p: Yes . You must tell me , now .

sp.speaker: MARY
sp.p: And I —She sits kneeling , looking straight ahead , and continues speaking , in a dead voiceI could n't help it . I put my arms around him .

sp.speaker: GUENEVERE
sp.p: Yes ?

lg.l: And he put his arms around me , Mrs. Robinson , and kissed me . And
I did n't care about anything else , then . I was glad . And then —

sp.speaker: GUENEVERE
sp.p: Yes ?

sp.speaker: MARY
sp.p: And then he woke up — and he was angry at me . He swore at me . And then he laughed , and kissed me again , and put me out of the room .

sp.speaker: GUENEVERE
sp.p: Yes , yes . And that — that was all ?

sp.speaker: MARY
sp.p: I came home . I thought I would have died . I knew I had been wicked . Oh , Mrs. Robinson —She breaks down and sobs .

sp.speaker: GUENEVERE
sp.p: patting her headPoor child , it 's all right . You are n't so wicked as you think . Oh , I 'm so glad !

sp.speaker: MARY
sp.p: But it 's jest the same , Mrs. Robinson . I wanted to be wicked .

sp.speaker: GUENEVERE
sp.p: Never mind , Mary . We all want to be wicked at times . But something always happens . It 's all right . You 're a good girl , Mary . There , stop crying !... Of course , of course ! I might have known . Lancelot could n't — and yet , I wonder .... Mary , stand up and let me look at you !

sp.speaker: MARY
sp.p: obeyingYes , ma'am .

sp.speaker: GUENEVERE
sp.p: in a strange toneYou 're a very good-looking girl , Mary .... So he laughed , and gave you a kiss , and led you to the door !... Well ! Go to bed and think no more about it . It 's all right .

sp.speaker: MARY
sp.p: Do you really think so , Mrs. Robinson ? Is n't it the same thing if you want to be wicked —

sp.speaker: GUENEVERE
sp.p: You 're talking like a professor of philosophy now , Mary . And you 're a woman , and you ought to know better . No , it is n't the same thing , at all . Run along , child .

sp.speaker: MARY
sp.p: Yes , ma'am . Thank you , ma'am . Good night , ma'am . She goes .

sp.speaker: GUENEVERE
sp.p: Good-night , Mary .She returns to her darning . She smiles to herself , then becomes serious , stops work , and looks at the clock . Then she says— Vivien ! Vivien 's tears ! Poor Lancelot ! Oh , well !She shrugs her shoulders , and goes on working . Then suddenly she puts down her work , rises , and walks restlessly about the room .... There is a knock at the door . She turns and stares at the door . The knock is repeated . She is silent , motionless for a moment . Then she says , almost in a whisper— Come ! A young man enters .

sp.speaker: GUENEVERE
sp.p: Lancelot !

sp.speaker: LANCELOT
sp.p: Guenevere !They go up to each other , and he takes both her hands . They stand that way for a moment . Then he says lightly— Darning King Arthur 's socks , I see !

sp.speaker: GUENEVERE
sp.p: releasing herself , and going back to her chairYes . Sit down .

sp.speaker: LANCELOT
sp.p: Where 's his royal highness ?

sp.speaker: GUENEVERE
sp.p: New York . Why do n't you ever come to see us ?

sp.speaker: LANCELOT
sp.p: not answeringCharming domestic picture !

sp.speaker: GUENEVERE
sp.p: Do n't be silly !

sp.speaker: LANCELOT
sp.p: I am going away .

sp.speaker: GUENEVERE
sp.p: Are you ? I 'm sorry . Do n't you like our little village ?

sp.speaker: LANCELOT
sp.p: Thought I 'd stop in to say good-bye .

sp.speaker: GUENEVERE
sp.p: That 's very sweet of you .

sp.speaker: LANCELOT
sp.p: risingI 've got to go back and finish packing .

sp.speaker: GUENEVERE
sp.p: Not really ?

sp.speaker: LANCELOT
sp.p: Going in the morning .

sp.speaker: GUENEVERE
sp.p: Why the haste ? The summer 's just begun . I hear you 've been doing some awfully good things . I was going over to see them .

sp.speaker: LANCELOT
sp.p: Thanks . Sorry to disappoint you . But I 've taken it into my head to leave .

sp.speaker: GUENEVERE
sp.p: You 're not going tonight , anyway . Sit down and talk to me .

sp.speaker: LANCELOT
sp.p: All right .He sits , constrainedly .What shall I talk about ?

sp.speaker: GUENEVERE
sp.p: smilingYour work .

sp.speaker: LANCELOT
sp.p: impatientlyYou 're not interested in my work .

sp.speaker: GUENEVERE
sp.p: Your love-affairs , then .

sp.speaker: LANCELOT
sp.p: Do n't want to .

sp.speaker: GUENEVERE
sp.p: Then read to me . There 's some books on the table .

sp.speaker: LANCELOT
sp.p: opening a serious-looking magazineHere 's an article on “ The Concept of Happiness ” — by Professor Arthur B. Robinson . Shall I read that ?

lg.l: I gather that you are not as fond of my husband as I am ,
Lancelot . But try to be nice to me , anyway . Read some poetry .

sp.speaker: LANCELOT
sp.p: takes a book from the table , and reads— “ It needs no maxims drawn from Socrates To tell me this is madness in my blood — ”

body.stage: He pauses . She looks up inquiringly . Presently he goes on reading — “ Nor does what wisdom I have learned from these Serve to abate my most unreasoned mood . What would I of you ? What gift could you bring , That to await you in the common street Sets all my secret ecstasy a-wing Into wild regions of sublime retreat ? And if you come , you will speak common words — ” He stops , and flings the book across the room . She looks up .

sp.speaker: GUENEVERE
sp.p: Do n't you like it ?

sp.speaker: LANCELOT
sp.p: gloomilyHell ! That 's too true .

sp.speaker: GUENEVERE
sp.p: Try something else .

lg.l: No — I can n't read .
Shall I go ?

sp.speaker: GUENEVERE
sp.p: No .

sp.speaker: LANCELOT
sp.p: Do you enjoy seeing me suffer ?

sp.speaker: GUENEVERE
sp.p: Does talking to me make you suffer ?

sp.speaker: LANCELOT
sp.p: Yes .

sp.speaker: GUENEVERE
sp.p: I 'm sorry .

sp.speaker: LANCELOT
sp.p: Then let me go .

sp.speaker: GUENEVERE
sp.p: No . Sit there and talk to me , like a rational human being .

sp.speaker: LANCELOT
sp.p: I 'm not a rational human being . I 'm a fool . A crazy fool .

sp.speaker: GUENEVERE
sp.p: smiling at himI like crazy fools .

sp.speaker: LANCELOT
sp.p: desperately , rising as he speaksI am going to be married .

sp.speaker: GUENEVERE
sp.p: in a mocking simulation of surpriseWhat , again ?

sp.speaker: LANCELOT
sp.p: Yes — again — and as soon as possible — to Vivien .

sp.speaker: GUENEVERE
sp.p: I congratulate you .

sp.speaker: LANCELOT
sp.p: I love her .

sp.speaker: GUENEVERE
sp.p: Naturally .

sp.speaker: LANCELOT
sp.p: She loves me .

sp.speaker: GUENEVERE
sp.p: I trust so .

sp.speaker: LANCELOT
sp.p: Then why should I be at this moment aching to kiss you ? Tell me that ?

sp.speaker: GUENEVERE
sp.p: looking at him calmlyIt does seem strange .

sp.speaker: LANCELOT
sp.p: It is absolutely insane ! It 's preposterous ! It 's contradictory !

sp.speaker: GUENEVERE
sp.p: Are you quite sure it 's all true ?

sp.speaker: LANCELOT
sp.p: Yes ! I 'm sure that I never would commit the rashness of matrimony again without being in love . Very much in love . And I 'm equally sure that I would not stand here and tell you what a fool I am about you , if that were n't true . Do you think I want to be this way ? It 's too ridiculous — I did n't want to tell you . I wanted to go . You made me stay . Well , now you know what a blithering lunatic I am .

sp.speaker: GUENEVERE
sp.p: quietlyIt is lunacy , is n't it ?

sp.speaker: LANCELOT
sp.p: Is it ?

sp.speaker: GUENEVERE
sp.p: Sheer lunacy . In love with one woman , and wanting to kiss another . Disgraceful , in fact .

sp.speaker: LANCELOT
sp.p: I know what you think ! You think I 'm paying you an extremely caddish compliment — or else —

sp.speaker: GUENEVERE
sp.p: earnestly , as she risesNo , I do n't think that at all , Lancelot . I believe you when you say that about me . And I do n't imagine for one moment that you 're not really in love with Vivien . I know you are . I could pretend to myself that you were n't — just as you 've tried to pretend to yourself sometimes , that I 'm not really in love with Arthur . But you know I am — do n't you ?

sp.speaker: LANCELOT
sp.p: Yes . ...

sp.speaker: GUENEVERE
sp.p: Well , Lancelot , there are — two lunatics here .He stares at her .It 's almost funny . I do n't know why I 'm telling you . But —

sp.speaker: LANCELOT
sp.p: You —!

sp.speaker: GUENEVERE
sp.p: Yes . I want to kiss you , too .

sp.speaker: LANCELOT
sp.p: But this wo n't do . As long as there was only one of us —

sp.speaker: GUENEVERE
sp.p: There 's been two all along , Lancelot . I 've more self-control than you — that 's all . But I broke down tonight . I knew I ought n't to tell you — now . But I knew I would .

sp.speaker: LANCELOT
sp.p: You , too ! They have unconsciously circled about to the opposite side of the room .

sp.speaker: GUENEVERE
sp.p: Oh , well , Lance , I fancy we are n't the only ones . It 's a common human failing , no doubt . Lots of people must feel this way .

sp.speaker: LANCELOT
sp.p: What do they do about it ?

sp.speaker: GUENEVERE
sp.p: Well , it all depends on what kind of people they are . Some of them go ahead and kiss . Others think of the consequences .

sp.speaker: LANCELOT
sp.p: Well , let 's think of the consequences , then . What are they ? I forget .

sp.speaker: GUENEVERE
sp.p: I do n't . I 'm keeping them very clearly in mind . In the first place —

sp.speaker: LANCELOT
sp.p: Yes ?

sp.speaker: GUENEVERE
sp.p: What was it ? Yes — in the first place , we would be sorry . And in the second place —

sp.speaker: LANCELOT
sp.p: In the second place —

sp.speaker: GUENEVERE
sp.p: In the second place — I forget what 's in the second place . But in the third place we must n't . Is n't that enough ?

sp.speaker: LANCELOT
sp.p: Yes . I know we must n't . But — I feel that we are going to .

sp.speaker: GUENEVERE
sp.p: Please do n't say that .

sp.speaker: LANCELOT
sp.p: But is n't it true ? Do n't you feel that , too ?

sp.speaker: GUENEVERE
sp.p: Yes .

sp.speaker: LANCELOT
sp.p: Then we 're lost .

sp.speaker: GUENEVERE
sp.p: No . We must think !

sp.speaker: LANCELOT
sp.p: I can n't think .

sp.speaker: GUENEVERE
sp.p: Try .

sp.speaker: LANCELOT
sp.p: It 's no use . I can n't even remember “ in the first place , ” now .

sp.speaker: GUENEVERE
sp.p: Then — before we do remember —! He takes her in his arms . They kiss each other — a long , long kiss .

sp.speaker: LANCELOT
sp.p: Sweetheart !

sp.speaker: GUENEVERE
sp.p: holding him at arm 's lengthThat was in the second place , Lancelot . If we kiss each other , we 'll begin saying things like that — and perhaps believing them .

sp.speaker: LANCELOT
sp.p: What did I say ?

sp.speaker: GUENEVERE
sp.p: Something very foolish .

sp.speaker: LANCELOT
sp.p: What , darling ?

sp.speaker: GUENEVERE
sp.p: There , you did it again . Stop , or I shall be doing it , too . I want to , you know .

sp.speaker: LANCELOT
sp.p: Want what ?

sp.speaker: GUENEVERE
sp.p: To call you darling , and believe I 'm in love with you .

sp.speaker: LANCELOT
sp.p: Are n't you ?

sp.speaker: GUENEVERE
sp.p: I must n't be .

sp.speaker: LANCELOT
sp.p: But are n't you ?

sp.speaker: GUENEVERE
sp.p: Oh , I —She closes her eyes , and he draws her to him . Suddenly she frees herself .No ! Lancelot — no ! I 'm not in love with you . And you 're not in love with me . We 're just two wicked people who want to kiss each other .

sp.speaker: LANCELOT
sp.p: Wicked ? I do n't feel wicked . Do you ?

sp.speaker: GUENEVERE
sp.p: No . I just feel natural . But it 's the same thing .He approaches her with outstretched arms . She retreats behind the chair .No , no . Remember that I 'm married .

sp.speaker: LANCELOT
sp.p: I do n't care .

sp.speaker: GUENEVERE
sp.p: Then remember that you 're engaged !

sp.speaker: LANCELOT
sp.p: Engaged ?

sp.speaker: GUENEVERE
sp.p: Yes : to Vivien .

sp.speaker: LANCELOT
sp.p: stopping shortSo I am .

sp.speaker: GUENEVERE
sp.p: And you 're in love with her .

sp.speaker: LANCELOT
sp.p: That 's true .

sp.speaker: GUENEVERE
sp.p: You see now that you can n't kiss me , do n't you ? LANCELOTdazedlyYes .

sp.speaker: GUENEVERE
sp.p: Then thank heavens ! for I was about to let you . And that 's in the fifth place , Lancelot : if we kiss each other once , we 're sure to do it again and again — and again . Now go over there and sit down , and we 'll talk sanely and sensibly .

sp.speaker: LANCELOT
sp.p: obeyingHeavens , what a moment ! I 'm not over it yet .

sp.speaker: GUENEVERE
sp.p: Neither am I . We 're a pair of sillies , are n't we ? I never thought I should ever behave in such a fashion .

sp.speaker: LANCELOT
sp.p: It was my fault . I should n't have started it .

sp.speaker: GUENEVERE
sp.p: I am as much to blame as you .

sp.speaker: LANCELOT
sp.p: I 'm sorry .

sp.speaker: GUENEVERE
sp.p: Are you ?

sp.speaker: LANCELOT
sp.p: I ought to be . But I 'm not , exactly .

sp.speaker: GUENEVERE
sp.p: I 'm not either , I 'm ashamed to say .

sp.speaker: LANCELOT
sp.p: The truth is , I want to kiss you again .

sp.speaker: GUENEVERE
sp.p: And I ... But do you call this talking sensibly ?

sp.speaker: LANCELOT
sp.p: I suppose it is n't . Well , go ahead with your sixth place , then . Only , for heaven 's sake try and say something that will really do some good !

sp.speaker: GUENEVERE
sp.p: Very well , Lancelot . Do you really want to elope with me ?

sp.speaker: LANCELOT
sp.p: Very much .

sp.speaker: GUENEVERE
sp.p: That 's not the right answer . You know perfectly well you want to do nothing of the sort . What ! Scandalize everybody , and ruin my reputation , and break Vivien 's heart ?

sp.speaker: LANCELOT
sp.p: No — I do n't suppose I really want to do any of those things .

sp.speaker: GUENEVERE
sp.p: Then do you want us to conduct a secret and vulgar intrigue ?

sp.speaker: LANCELOT
sp.p: hurtGuenevere !

sp.speaker: GUENEVERE
sp.p: You realize , of course , that this madness of ours might last no longer than a month ?

sp.speaker: LANCELOT
sp.p: soberlyPerhaps .

sp.speaker: GUENEVERE
sp.p: Well , do you still want to kiss me ?— Think what you are saying , Lancelot , for I may let you . And that kiss may be the beginning of the catastrophe .She moves toward him .Do you want a kiss that brings with it grief and fear and danger and heartbreak ?

sp.speaker: LANCELOT
sp.p: No —

sp.speaker: GUENEVERE
sp.p: Then what do you want ?

sp.speaker: LANCELOT
sp.p: I want — a kiss .

sp.speaker: GUENEVERE
sp.p: Never . If you had believed , for one your chance .

sp.speaker: LANCELOT
sp.p: Kiss me !

sp.speaker: GUENEVERE
sp.p: Never . If you had believed , for one moment , that it was worth the price of grief and heartbreak , I should have believed it too , and kissed you , and not cared what happened . I should have risked the love of my husband and the happiness of your sweetheart without a qualm . And who knows ? It might have been worth it . An hour from now I shall be sure it was n't ; I shall be sure it was all blind , wicked folly . But now I am a little sorry . I wanted to gamble with fate . I wanted us to stake our two lives recklessly upon a kiss — and see what happened . And you could n't . It was n't a moment of beauty and terror to you . You did n't want to challenge fate . You just wanted to kiss me .... Go !

sp.speaker: LANCELOT
sp.p: turning on her bitterlyYou women ! Because you are afraid , you accuse us of being cowards .

sp.speaker: GUENEVERE
sp.p: What do you mean ?

sp.speaker: LANCELOT
sp.p: brutallyYou ! You want a love-affair . Your common sense tells you it 's folly . Your reason wo n't allow it . So you want your common sense to be overwhelmed , your reason lost . You want to be swept off your , feet . You want to be made to do something you do n't approve of . You want to be wicked , and you want it to be some one else 's fault . Tell me — is n't it true ?

sp.speaker: GUENEVERE
sp.p: Yes , it is true — except for one thing , Lancelot . It 's true that I wanted you to sweep me off my feet , to make me forget everything ; it was wrong , it was foolish of me to want it , but I did . Only if you had done it , you would n't have been “ to blame . ” I should have loved you for ever because you could do it . And now , because you could n't I despise you . Now you know . ... Go .

sp.speaker: LANCELOT
sp.p: No , Guenevere , you do n't despise me . You 're angry with me and angry with yourself because you could n't quite forget King Arthur . You are blaming me and I am blaming you , is n't it amusing ?

sp.speaker: GUENEVERE
sp.p: You are right , Lancelot . It 's my fault . Oh , I envy women who can dare to make fools of themselves who forget everything and do n't care what they do ! I suppose that 's love — and I 'm not up to it .

sp.speaker: LANCELOT
sp.p: You are different ....

sp.speaker: GUENEVERE
sp.p: Different ? Yes , I 'm a coward . I 'm not primitive enough . Despise me . You 've a right to . And — please go .

sp.speaker: LANCELOT
sp.p: I 'm afraid I 'm not very primitive either , Gwen . I —

sp.speaker: GUENEVERE
sp.p: I 'm afraid you 're not , Lance . That 's the trouble with us . We 're civilized . Hopelessly civilized . We had a spark of the old barbaric flame — but it went out . We put it out — quenched it with conversation . No , Lancelot , we 've talked our hour away . It 's time for you to pack up . Good-bye .He kisses her hand lingeringly .You may kiss my lips if you like . There 's not the slightest danger . We were unnecessarily alarmed about ourselves . We could n't misbehave ! ... Going ?

sp.speaker: LANCELOT
sp.p: Damn you ! Good-bye ! He goes .

sp.speaker: GUENEVERE
sp.p: Well , that did it . If he had stayed a moment longer —! She flings up her arms in a wild gesture — then recovers herself , and goes to her chair , where she sits down and quietly resumes the darning of her husband 's socks .
